Emergency Response and Preparation
Goal 5-7:          Maintain a high level of emergency response capability.
Policy 5-7.1:      Update, on a regular basis, the City Hazard Mitigation
                   Plan.
Policy 5-7.2:      Provide training to all City employees on their roles and
                   responsibilities in times of disasters and local
                   emergencies. Training should include comprehensive and
                   realistic disaster exercises.
Policy 5-7.3:      Increase the City’s ability to coordinate and control its
                   resources in an emergency situation by improving the
                   operational capacity of the Emergency Operating Center,
                   by identifying local resources available, and by
                   developing contracts and agreements for utilizing these
                   resources in an emergency.
Policy 5-7.4:      Distribute and/or publicize established emergency
                   preparedness plans to increase public awareness.
Goal 5-8:          Provide effective and comprehensive policing services
                   that meet the safety needs of Rialto.
Policy 5-8.1:      Provide timely responses to emergency and non-
                   emergency call for service 24 hours a day, per the City
                   standards.
Policy 5-8.2:      Establish the satellite Police Department in the northwest
                   neighborhood.
Policy 5-8.3:      Continue to encourage design concepts that inhibit and
                   discourage criminal behavior, such as Crime Prevention
                   Through Environmental Design (CPTED) techniques.
Policy 5-8.4:      Initiate proactive crime suppression and prevention
                   strategies throughout the community.
Gangs
Goal 5-9:          Reduce criminal gang activity and discourage gang
                   involvement in the City of Rialto.
Policy 5-9.1:      Identify specific high crime areas in the City and when
                   feasible, create plans/strategies to improve these areas.
  Page        Chapter
  5-26           5

                           THE SAFETY AND NOISE CHAPTER
Policy 5-9.2:  Provide immediate consequences for minor criminal
               behavior.
Policy 5-9.3:  Continue to work with law enforcement agencies, San
               Bernardino County Probation, State Parole, and the
               District Attorney’s Office in their endeavors to arrest and
               prosecute violent gang members.
Policy 5-9.4:  Work with State parole officials to identify gang members
               recently released from prison, and develop orientation
               programs that inform them of services available in the
               community to help them get back on their feet.
Policy 5-9.4:  Continue to work with the San Bernardino Movement
               Against Street Hoodlums (SMASH) to identify and clean
               up street gangs.
Policy 5-9.5:  Enforce gang injunctions where needed to address
               neighborhood gang problems before they reach a level of
               felony crime activity.
Policy 5-9.6:  Support Neighborhood Watch Programs.
Policy 5-9.7:  Encourage street and graffiti cleanup.
Policy 5-9.8:  Continue to provide community programs that develop
               positive relationships between the Rialto Police
               Department and community members, such as the Area
               Commander Program and Crime Free Multi-Housing
               Program, which provide a safe and secure environment
               for the community to discuss gang-related issues and
               effective solutions to help reduce crime and provide a
               safer living environment.
Policy 5-9.9:  Provide youth and family programs such as after-school
               recreational programs, volunteer programs, and job
               placements or internship programs that will help spark
               positive interests and discourage youth from participating
               in gang-related activities.
Noise
Goal 5-10:     Minimize the impact of point source and ambient noise
               levels throughout the community.
Policy 5-10.1: Revise the City’s noise ordinance to address ongoing
               noise issues by using quantitative noise limits where
               appropriate and establishing comprehensive noise
               control measures.

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Policy 5-10.2:    Consider noise impacts as part of the development
                  review process, particularly the location of parking,
                  ingress/egress/loading, and refuse collection areas
                  relative to surrounding residential development and other
                  noise-sensitive land uses.
Policy 5-10.3:    Ensure that acceptable noise levels are maintained near
                  schools, hospitals, and other noise sensitive areas in
                  accordance with the Municipal Code and noise standards
                  contained in Exhibit 5-5.
Policy 5-10.4:    Limit the hours of operation at all noise generation
                  sources that are adjacent to noise-sensitive areas.
Policy 5-10.5:    Require all exterior noise sources (construction
                  operations, air compressors, pumps, fans and leaf
                  blowers) to use available noise suppression devices and
                  techniques to reduce exterior noise to acceptable levels
                  that are compatible with adjacent land uses.
Goal 5-11:        Minimize the impacts of transportation-related noise.
Policy 5-11.1:    Work with responsible Federal and State agencies to
                  minimize the impact of transportation-related noise,
                  including noise associated with freeways, major arterials,
                  and Metrolink and other rail lines.
Policy 5-11.2:    Require development which is, or will be, affected by
                  railroad noise to include appropriate measures to
                  minimize adverse noise effects on residents and business
                  persons.
Policy 5-11.3:    Require development of truck-intensive uses to minimize
                  noise impacts on adjacent uses through appropriate site
                  design.
Policy 5-11.4:    Develop a program for monitoring noise levels and
                  investigating complaints.
Policy 5-11.5:    Provide education to the community at large about the
                  importance of maintaining a healthy noise environment,
                  and identify ways residents can assist in noise abatement
                  efforts.

                                                        HOUSING ELEMENT
Introduction
The Housing Element provides the City with a coordinated and
comprehensive strategy for promoting the production of safe, decent, and
affordable housing for all within the community.
Role and Organization of the Housing Element
The Housing Element is one of seven mandatory General Plan elements.
The Element identifies ways in which the housing needs of current and future
residents can be met. Consistent with State Housing Element laws, it must be
updated every five years unless otherwise extended by legislation. This
Housing Element covers the period extending from July 1, 2008 to June 30,
2014.
The Housing Element consists of the following major components:
       An introduction of the purpose and organization of the Housing
        Element
       An analysis of the City’s demographic and housing characteristics
        and trends
       A review of potential market, governmental, and environmental
        constraints to meeting the City’s identified housing needs
       An evaluation of land, administrative, and financial resources
        available to address the housing goals
       A review of past accomplishments under the previous Housing
        Element
       A Housing Plan to address the identified housing needs, including
        housing goals, policies, and programs
State Requirements and Legislative Changes
The California Legislature has determined that a primary housing goal for the
State is ensuring every resident has a decent home and suitable living
environment. Section 65580 of the California Government Codes describes
the goal in detail:
a.      The availability of housing is of vital statewide importance, and the
        early attainment of decent housing and a suitable living environment
        for every Californian, including farmworkers, is a priority of the
        highest order.
b.      The early attainment of this goal requires cooperative participation of
        government and the private sector in an effort to expand housing
                                                                                Chapter Page
                                                                                   6     6-1

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
          opportunities and accommodate the housing needs of Californians of
          all economic levels.
c.        The provision of housing affordable to low- and moderate-income
          households requires the cooperation of all levels of the government.
d.        Local and state governments have a responsibility to use the powers
          vested in them to facilitate the improvement and development of
          housing to make adequate provision for housing needs of all
          economic segments of the community.
e.        The Legislature recognizes that in carrying out this responsibility,
          each local government also has the responsibility to consider
          economic, environmental, and fiscal factors and community goals set
          forth in the general plan and to cooperate with other local
          governments and the state in addressing regional housing needs.
State law requires housing elements to be updated every five years to reflect
a community’s changing housing needs, unless such timeline is otherwise
extended by State legislation. The Government Code also requires that each
draft housing element be reviewed by the California Department of Housing
and Community Development (HCD) and that HCD’s findings be
incorporated prior to adoption, or that specified findings be made in
response to HCD’s comments.
In response to changing State laws pertaining to the housing element, this
updated Housing Element addresses recent changes to State laws intended
to facilitate and expedite the construction of affordable housing:
         Extremely Low Income – AB2635 requires local jurisdictions to
          assess the housing needs of extremely low-income households, in
          addition to the established requirement to examine the needs of
          very-low, low-, and moderate-income households. Extremely low
          income are those that earn 0 to 30 percent of the Area Median
          Income. The community needs assessment includes extremely low-
          income households in discussions on housing need.
         Land Inventory and Analysis – AB2348 (Chapter 724) amended
          housing element law to include more specific requirements for the
          content of the land inventory and analysis section. Specifically, the
          land inventory must include site-specific listing of available land
          inventory, including the parcel number or “unique” reference. The
          land inventory is included at the end of the Element in Table H-48.
         Constraints for Persons with Disabilities – SB520 requires that
          housing elements identify potential and actual constraints upon the
          development, maintenance, and improvement of housing for persons
          with disabilities. The Constraints section addresses possible
          constraints for housing for persons with disabilities.
   Page         Chapter
    6-2            6

                                                       HOUSING ELEMENT
       Emergency Shelters – SB2, Chapter 633 requires that local
        government assess homeless need and identify opportunities for
        addressing this need. Program 7 is included in the Housing Plan to
        comply with State law.
Relationship to Other General Plan Elements
The Rialto General Plan consists of the following elements: Managing the
Land Supply, Investing in the Future, Circulation, Safety and Noise, Housing,
and Cultural and Historic Resources, as well as an Implementation Program.
The Housing Element builds upon the other Elements and is consistent with
the General Plan’s policies and proposals. The Housing Element draws upon
the development capacity levels provided for in the Managing the Land
Supply Element to determine the appropriate location for affordable housing
development.
Public Participation
As a part of the comprehensive update of all General Plan elements, the
General Plan team undertook a series of more than 35 interviews with
stakeholders and a citywide visioning effort that touched more than 500
people. In addition, a General Plan Action Committee — made up of 20
Rialto residents appointed by the City Council, the Planning Commission,
and other key City bodies and departments — met three times to formulate a
set of Guiding Principles, act as the lead group for Visioneering (an informal,
grassroots process for obtaining community input), and review and approve
the draft Land Use Plan.
To capture input from Housing Element stakeholders, a draft copy of the
Element will be provided to the groups identified below, whose feedback
will be incorporated into the final Housing Element as appropriate. In
addition, the draft Element will be published on the City’s website and
available for public comment.
Housing Element stakeholders include:
       Home AID
       Southern California Presbyterian Homes (SCPH)
       National CORE: Housing Action Resource Trust (HART)
       Neighborhood Housing Services of the Inland Empire, Inc.
       The East Los Angeles Community Union (TELACU)

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Data Sources
Data from a variety of resources inform the crafting of the Housing Element.
One of the most cited sources is the 2000 U.S, Census. The Census,
although dated, provides consistent demographic characteristics that are
widely accepted. California Department of Finance (DOF) 2007 Population
and Housing Estimates supplement the 2000 Census data. Additional
information has been drawn from the 2004 Comprehensive Housing
Affordability Strategy (CHAS) data. CHAS data are based on special
tabulations for the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
(HUD) from sample Census data.
Population and Housing Profile
This section provides an overview of housing and population conditions in
Rialto. This profile serves as a foundation and starting point for the update to
the City’s Housing Element as required by HCD. Housing needs vary by
demographic and household characteristics, cultural backgrounds and
preferences, and income, as well as other special circumstances.
Determining housing needs in Rialto requires understanding population
growth trends, age, race/ethnicity, and employment characteristics.
Data Limitations
The data used in this needs assessment have been collected from the U.S.
Census (1990 and 2000 Census, 2005 American Community Survey),
California DOF 2009 estimates, and various other sources. Utilizing
estimates for demographic data shows changes in conditions since the 2000
Census. However, many of these estimates (such as the 2005 American
Community Survey and DOF data) are shown solely as percentages. The raw
numbers carry a significant margin of error, especially for smaller
geographies such as counties or cities. Nonetheless, the percentages
presented give a general indication of population and employment trends.
Additional information is drawn from the 2004 CHAS data, which is drawn
from Census 2000 data. CHAS data are based on special tabulations from
sample Census data. Thus, the number of households in each category often
deviates slightly from the 100 percent count due to extrapolations to the
total household level. Because of this, interpretations of CHAS data should
focus on proportions and percentages rather than on precise numbers.
Summary
The City of Rialto is composed of diverse and vital, predominantly detached
single-family home neighborhoods. Continuing to provide adequate and
affordable housing to its residents is a goal of the City and this Housing
   Page       Chapter
    6-4            6

                                                                    HOUSING ELEMENT
Element. One of the largest cities in San Bernardino County, Rialto’s
population is expected to continue to grow, especially with young residents.
Over two-thirds of the population is Latino or Hispanic, and the median
income is slightly higher than San Bernardino County average. The majority
of households in the community own their homes, with a housing stock
composed primarily of single-family homes. Due to the increases in home
prices over the last ten years, half of the residents experience a housing cost
burden (paying more than 30 percent of their income for housing), and over
ten percent live in overcrowded conditions. The Southern California
Association of Governments’ Regional Housing Needs Assessment (RHNA)
has determined that Rialto’s fair share allocation is 4,323 new housing units
for this planning period (2008-2014).
Community Location
Rialto is located in the western portion of San Bernardino County,
approximately 60 miles east of Los Angeles. The City is intersected (east to
west) by two major freeways: the I-10 freeway in the south and the SR-210
freeway in the north. The City neighbors the city of Fontana on the west and
the city of Colton on the east. Originally an agricultural town, Rialto’s
development was heavily influenced by the establishment of Route 66
(Foothill Boulevard) and the Pacific Electric railroad. These two
developments increased regional connectivity to Los Angeles and influenced
overall growth in Rialto.
Population Characteristics
According to the 2000 Census, the population of Rialto was 91,873 persons.
In 2007 the State Department of Finance estimated a population of 100,022,
representing nearly nine percent growth since the Census. A demographic
profile by the geographic information system software company ESRI
showed an 11 percent population growth, with a 2006 population of
101,563.1 The population is close to evenly split between male and female
residents (51 percent and 49 percent, respectively2).
Rialto is the sixth largest city in the San Bernardino County, behind the cities
of San Bernardino, Fontana, Rancho Cucamonga, Ontario, and Victorville.
Like many cities in the Inland Empire, Rialto experienced significant
population growth in the past 20 years and can be expected to continue to
grow due to available land resources and relative affordability. The Southern
California Association of Governments (SCAG) indicates that by 2025, one

Future growth estimates predict a slower increase in population over the
next 20 years. SCAG estimates that the population of Rialto will top 111,000
by the year 2030, an average population increase of 2.58% per year
between 2010 and 2030. The average annual population change for Rialto
between 1980 and 2000 was 7.13%.
Age Composition
The age structure of a population is an important factor in evaluating
housing needs. The traditional assumption is that in many communities,
young adults tend to prefer apartments, low- to moderate-cost
condominiums, and smaller or more affordable single-family units, while
mature adults provide the market for moderate- to high-end condominiums
and single-family homes. The senior population (65 years and older) tends
to generate demand for low- to moderate-cost apartments and
condominiums, community residential settings, and mobile homes.
San Bernardino County as a whole can be characterized as having a young
population. Among Southern California counties, San Bernardino has the
youngest median age at 30.2 years (compared with Los Angeles, Orange,
Riverside, San Diego and Ventura counties).4 Rialto is representative of this
characteristic, with a median age in 2005 of 28.2. In Rialto, preschool and
school age residents comprised over a third of the population in 2005.
Young adults between the age of 25 and 44 comprised close to 30 percent
of the population. Although residents 65 years and older make up only
about eight percent of the total population, the large proportion of adults
over 45 years of age is indicative of the aging baby boomer population that
will likely change the demographic and economic dynamic of the City over
the next 15 to 20 years.

Race and Ethnicity
In 2005, most Rialto residents were Hispanic or white. Constituting 45
percent and 38 percent of the population, respectively, this population
characteristic is indicative of the demographic shifts that have occurred in
Rialto over the past 15 to 20 years. In 1990, white residents comprised
almost half of the population. As the Hispanic population has grown, the
proportion of white and African American population has declined.
The racial and ethnic composition of a community affects housing needs due
to the varying household characteristics and preferences sometimes
associated with different groups. In 2000, for example, the average
household size in Rialto was 3.7. Hispanic and Asian households had a
comparatively larger average household size (4.52 and 4.16, respectively),
indicating a potential increase in demand for larger housing units if the
Hispanic population continues to grow.

Employment
Rialto residents are employed in diverse industries, with the largest percent
employed in the educational, health, and social services sector. This sector
includes those who work for the largest local employer, the Rialto Unified
School District. The second-most common sector to work in is
manufacturing, with over 16 percent of residents employed in the industry.
Retail trade ranks third, with 14.4 percent working in retail. This sector is
important to consider when assessing housing affordability, as retail salaries
tend to be lower, which decreases the amount of income available for
housing. The retail sector also generally does not offer health and other
employment benefits, further increasing economic strain.

Rialto has been particularly hard hit by job losses in the recession following
the real estate, banking, and credit crises of 2007 and 2008. Whereas the
unemployment rate in the City had generally hovered about two percentage
points higher than that of San Bernardino County as a whole, in 2009 that
gap increased to three and even four points. By November 2009, the
unemployment rate for the City was over 18 percent, meaning that nearly
one in five City residents was unemployed. For the County during the same
month the rate was just over 14 percent, or nearly one in seven.

Household Characteristics
Household type and size, income level, the presence of persons with special
needs, and other household characteristics may affect access to and demand
for housing and housing programs. This section details the various
household characteristics in Rialto.
A household is defined by the Census as all persons occupying a housing
unit. Families are a subset of households and include all persons living
together who are related by blood, marriage, or adoption.              Single
households include persons living alone in housing units, but do not include
persons in group quarters such as convalescent homes or dormitories.
Other households are unrelated people living together, such as roommates.
Household Type
In 2000, the U.S. Census estimated that Rialto had 24,659 households. In
2005, the Census estimated a 2.4 percent increase in the number of
households. The distribution of households as indicated by 2000 and 2005
  Page       Chapter
  6-10          6

                                                         HOUSING ELEMENT
Census data show that the majority of households in the Rialto are families.
Families headed by single parents made up 15 percent of all households.

Household composition and size are often two interrelated factors.
Communities with a large proportion of families with children tend to have a
large average household size. Such communities have a greater need for
larger units with adequate open space and recreational opportunities for
children. While the Census in 2000 and 2005 showed that household size
remained relatively stable, there was a slight increase, and household size
remains higher than that of San Bernardino County. The County average
household size was 3.15 in 2000 and 3.26 in 2005.
Tenure
Tenure in the housing industry typically refers to the occupancy of a housing
unit – whether the unit is owner-occupied or renter-occupied. Tenure
preferences are primarily related to household income, composition, and
age of the householder. The tenure distribution (owner versus renter) of a
community’s housing stock influences several aspects of the local housing
market. Residential mobility is influenced by tenure, with ownership housing
evidencing a much lower turnover rate than rental housing. Rialto’s housing
stock is predominantly owner-occupied, at a slightly higher rate than the
County as a whole. Although the level of owner-occupied housing dipped
slightly in 2000, it has remained relatively stable since 1990.

Foreclosures
The 2007-2009 economic crisis has resulted in a dramatic increase in the
number of foreclosures for households with sub-prime loans. In many cases,
financing for these homes was made through the sub-prime credit market.
Sub-prime loans are characterized by higher interest rates and fees than
prime loans, and are more likely to include prepayment penalties. The
foreclosure problem overall has been a significant problem throughout
Southern California, particularly in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties.
Household Income
In 2005 the median household income in Rialto was estimated at $50,446,
only slightly higher than the San Bernardino County median income of
$49,026. Household income is an important consideration when evaluating
housing conditions because lower incomes typically constrain people's
ability to obtain adequate housing. Income in Rialto varied significantly for
different types of households, indicating that specific family types will have
greater need for affordable housing and housing services. For example,
married couple families had a much higher median income ($64,262) than
families headed by a single female ($29,013). As explained above, 82
percent of households in Rialto identify themselves as families. Table 6-5 is
representative of families only, and does not include the other 18 percent of
households that are singles or do not identify as part of a family.

Housing Stock Characteristics
The Census Bureau defines a housing unit as a house, an apartment, a
mobile home, a group of rooms, or a single room that is occupied (or, if
vacant, is intended for occupancy) as separate living quarters. Separate
living quarters are those in which the occupants live separately from any
other individuals in the building and which have direct access from outside
the building or through a common hall.
Housing Growth
The number of housing units in Rialto has increased 12 percent since 1990.
New development in Rialto is expected to increase the housing stock further
over the next five to 15 years, particularly in northern Rialto where proximity
to SR-210 is creating expanded opportunities for development within the
Pepper Avenue, Lytle Creek, and Rialto Renaissance Specific Plan areas. The
recession that began in late 2007 has significantly affected homebuilders’
decisions to continue the prior pace of growth, and this condition is
anticipated to continue during a portion of this Housing Element cycle.

Housing Type
The housing stock composition in Rialto has remained stable since 2000.
Single-family detached houses are the principal housing type in the City;
multi-family units make up 20 percent of the total housing units.
Nearly seven percent of the housing units in Rialto are mobile homes, which
have filled an affordable housing niche for years. As land values rise,
however, the parks on which mobile homes are standing have increased
likelihood of being sold and redeveloped. The City created a Mobile Home
Development zone in 1980 to preserve mobile homes for affordable

uses in this zone are mobile home parks. As such, a zone change would be

Age of Housing Stock
The age of housing is commonly used as a measure of when housing may
begin to require repairs. In general, housing units over 30 years old are
likely to have rehabilitation needs, including new roofing, foundation work,
and new plumbing. The median year built for housing units in the City is
1978. This makes more than half the City’s housing units 30 years of age or
older. The figure below also indicates that the City experienced tremendous
growth in the 1980s and very little growth since 2000.

Housing Problems
The Comprehensive Housing Affordability Strategy (CHAS) was developed
by the Census for HUD. It uses Census data to evaluate housing problems
for different groups, including elderly and large families. The CHAS identified
the following housing problems in Rialto:
        Severe Housing Cost Burden, including utilities, greater than 50
         percent of household income
        Housing Cost Burden, including utilities, between 30 and 50 percent
         of household income
        Overcrowded conditions (homes with more than one person per
         room, excluding kitchens and hallways)
        Units with physical problems or lack of suitable conditions (lacking
         plumbing facilities, for example)
In general, renters in Rialto are more likely than owners to experience
housing cost burden or other housing problems. However, low-income (with
incomes of 50 to 80 percent of the MFI) owner households are significantly
more likely than low-income renter households to experience a cost burden,
and more low-income households own than rent.
CHAS data also reveal that nearly half (44 percent) of Rialto households are
extremely low, very low, or low income, earning less than 80 percent of the
MFI. Of these households, over three quarters (76.5 percent) experienced
one or more housing problems, especially housing cost burden.

Overcrowding
Overcrowding occurs when housing costs are so high relative to income that
families have to live in small units or double up to devote income to other
basic needs such as food or medical care. However, cultural differences also
contribute to the overcrowded conditions since some cultures tend to have
larger household size than others due to the preference of living with
extended family members. The federal government defines an overcrowded
household as one with more than one person per room, excluding
bathrooms, kitchens, hallways, and porches. Severely overcrowded
households are households with greater than 1.5 persons per room. By
these definitions, approximately 21 percent of households in Rialto live in
overcrowded conditions in 2000.
The 2005 American Community Survey showed a decline in overcrowded
conditions. Generally, low-income families are disproportionately affected by
overcrowding. Overcrowding is also more prevalent among renters than
among owners. Rialto households in renter-occupied units experienced
overcrowding and severe overcrowding at a significantly higher proportion
than households in owner-occupied units. Over 2,250 renter households and
more than 2,750 owner households experienced overcrowded conditions in
2000.

Housing Cost Burden
State and federal standards specify that a household experiences a housing
cost burden if it pays 30 percent or more of its gross income on housing.
Housing cost burden typically is linked to income levels and occurs when
housing costs increase faster than income.
In Rialto, housing cost burden is more prevalent among renters than owners.
In 2000, the Census estimated that almost half (48 percent) of renter
households paid 30 percent or more of their gross income on housing. Over
two-thirds of renters with incomes of less than $35,000 per year experienced
a housing cost burden. In owner-occupied housing units, cost burden was
experienced by 36 percent of the households. Again, this burden was more
often felt by lower-income households, with nearly three-quarters of
households with incomes less than $35,000 paying more than 30 percent of
their income on housing.
The cost burden increased for both renters and owners in 2005 according to
the American Community Survey, estimated at 54 percent and 41 percent
respectively. Housing cost burden remains higher in Rialto than average for
San Bernardino County. Severe cost burden (paying 50 percent or more of
gross income on housing) was experienced by 12 percent of owners and
nearly a quarter of renters in 2000.
Low-income households are those that make less than 80 percent of the
median income. The median income for a family of four in San Bernardino
County is $59,200. As such, households (with four members) making less
than $47,350 per year are considered lower income. Exhibit 6-6reveals that
lower-income households are significantly more likely to experience housing
cost burden than higher-income households.

households experienced housing cost burden in 2000. According to the
CHAS (2004), almost all rental households (3,488 households) experiencing
housing cost burden were lower income (0-80% MFI), and over 3,600 lower
income owners paid more than 30 percent of their income on housing costs.

Substandard Housing Conditions
A variety of housing conditions can cause a home to be considered
substandard. These homes often require extensive renovation to make a
home safe. The number of homes that are likely to need major renovations
can be estimated by examining the percentage of older housing units and
Census reports of residents regarding their housing conditions.
Because half of the housing stock (over 14,000 units) will be more than 30
years old by 2009, significant rehabilitation needs are likely. The older
residential neighborhoods in Rialto are likely to require the most significant
rehabilitation, including seismic reinforcement in addition to maintenance
and repairs. The eastern portion of the City has the oldest housing stock and
therefore is likely to have the highest number of rehabilitation needs.
Additionally, the likelihood of homes with lead paint hazards increases for
those built before 1980. City staff estimates that 30 percent of single family
and 50 percent of multi-family housing need substantial rehabilitation.
The Census reports the number of housing conditions that each individual
household reports. These conditions include housing cost burden,
   Page        Chapter
   6-18            6

                                                           HOUSING ELEMENT
overcrowding, and lack of plumbing or kitchen facilities. Nearly five percent
of owners and almost 11 percent of renters reported two or more housing
conditions in 2005.
Foreclosure Rates
Foreclosure is a process by which lenders sell or take ownership of a
property because a homeowner has defaulted on the loan. The foreclosure
process begins after a homeowner has not paid for three consecutive
months, and the lender files a public Notice of Default, or lis pendens. The
process proceeds in one of four ways:
1.   The homeowner pays the default amount during a given grace period.
2.   The homeowner sells the home to another party.
3.   The home is placed on public auction.
4.   The lender takes possession of the house.
The 2007-2010 economic crisis has resulted in a dramatic increase in the
number of foreclosures for households with sub-prime loans. In many cases,
financing for these homes was made through the sub-prime credit market.
Sub-prime loans are characterized by higher interest rates and fees than
prime loans, and are more likely to include prepayment penalties. The
foreclosure problem overall has been a significant problem throughout
Southern California, particularly in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties.
                                         Table 6‐10

         San Diego                3931           6,151           8,975             5,543

                                                    San Bernardino County 
Unfortunately, many households losing their homes are the low-income
families that “predatory lenders” target. Denied conventional home loans,
their only avenue may have been the “subprime” credit market. Subprime
loans are characterized by higher interest rates and fees than prime loans,
and are more likely to include prepayment penalties. These predatory
lenders typically offer to refinance an existing loan with one that is filled with
excessive or unnecessary fees and usually provides no tangible benefit to the
borrower. These loans also often include adjustable rate mortgages with
steep built-in rate and payment increases and more onerous prepayment
penalties – and are usually approved with little or no income documentation
required.
In a recent change, most homeowners who default are unable to refinance,
sell their home, or become current with payments in another way, and
emerge from the foreclosure process without losing their homes. According
to DataQuick, the overall weakness of the real estate market has made
lender “work-outs” much more difficult then they had been in the past. In an
October 2008 news release from the real estate information company, only
20 percent of California homeowners who went into default that year were
able to keep their homes from being taken over by the mortgage lender. This
number was down from 60 percent the year before and 91 percent the year
before that. When households lose their home through foreclosure, it is
likely they will seek rental housing, and this may result in a higher demand
for rental units and thus push rents higher in Rialto and other communities in
San Bernardino and Riverside Counties.
Housing Cost and Affordability
The cost of housing in a community is directly correlated to the number of
housing problems and affordability issues. High housing costs can price low-
   Page      Chapter
   6-20            6

                                                       HOUSING ELEMENT
income families out of the market, cause extreme cost burdens, or force
households into overcrowded or substandard conditions.
Ownership Housing
Nearly three-quarters of households in Rialto live in owner-occupied
dwellings, with 73 percent of the housing units being single-family residential.
Beginning in mid-2007 the housing market collapse started to have a serious
effect on housing prices in Rialto, as it did throughout the State and most of
the nation. In May 2007, the median price of a home sold in Rialto was
about $380,000; by December of that year it had dropped $90,000 to
$290,000. By May 2009, it was $130,000. It remains unclear when or if the
housing market will return to its former heights, though the end of 2009 did
see a slight increase in median price.

Rental Housing
According to the Census, 29 percent of Rialto households live in rental
housing. These housing units are composed primarily of apartments, as well
as some condominiums, townhomes, and single-family residences.

During January 2009, rents in Rialto ranged from $675 to $900 for a studio
apartment, $800 to $1,200 for a one-bedroom, between $995 and $1,525
for a two-bedroom, and between $1,100 and $1,900 for a three-bedroom

Due to the large number of single-family homes in Rialto, a number are also

prices vary by size, number of bedrooms, and location, with the median rent
being $1,750 per month. Most homes for rent are either three- or four-

Housing Affordability
Income Levels and Affordable Housing Payments
Housing affordability levels are determined by HCD and divided into the
following categories:
       Extremely Low Income = income less than 30 percent of area
        Median Family Income (MFI)
       Very Low Income = income greater than 30 percent and less than 50
        percent MFI
       Lower Income = income greater than 50 percent and less than 80
        percent MFI
       Moderate Income = income greater than 80 percent and less than
        120 percent MFI
The California Health and Safety Code Section 50052.5 provides the
following definition of affordable housing cost based on income level:
              Calculation of Affordable Housing 
                             Cost                      Owner               Rental 
           Extremely Low (0-30% MFI)                30% of 30% AMI     30% of 30% AMI
           Very Low (0-50% MFI)                     30% of 50% AMI     30% of 50% AMI
           Lower (51-80% MFI)                       30% of 70% AMI     30% of 60% AMI
           Moderate Income (81-120% MFI)           35% of 110% AMI     30% of 110% AMI
HUD conducts an annual household survey to determine MFI and related
income amounts for low-income groups. Housing affordability for various
levels of income can be determined by estimating the costs of owning or
renting a home, including utilities, and applicable taxes or insurance, in
addition to the monthly payment on a mortgage or to a landlord.

The citywide home median price of $380,000 puts affordable
homeownership out of reach for most very low-, lower-, and moderate-
income households. Many newer low-income residents of Rialto are
confined to rental housing because the price of homes remains so high. The
problem of affordability remains in the rental market as well. It is difficult to
find any housing available in Rialto for less than $700 per month, pricing out
all very low- and extremely low-income households unless they are able to
receive subsidies.
Very low-income residents and families in Rialto cannot afford any of the
median priced rental units in the City, with a studio renting for a median
$799. Lower-income small families (three persons) can afford the median
price for a one-bedroom apartment, and a four-person lower-income family
can afford the median price for a two-bedroom apartment. Large lower-
   Page        Chapter
    6-24           6

                                                          HOUSING ELEMENT
income families, however, would not be able to afford a three-bedroom
apartment at the median price.
Housing Affordability Index
The California Building Industry Association publishes a quarterly housing
affordability index. The index calculates the percentage of homes that were
sold during a three-month period that would be affordable to a family
earning the region’s median income. The index assumes buyers will finance
90 percent of the purchase price with a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, and
takes into account prevailing interest rates, property taxes, and insurance
costs.
During the second and third quarters of 2008, the Riverside-San Bernardino-
Ontario metropolitan area moved from 35th to 64th in a listing of the least
affordable metro areas in the country. By comparison, in the last quarter of
2006 and the first of 2007 the rankings were 11th and 14th, respectively.
During the fourth quarter of 2006, only 6.8 percent of the homes in the
metro area were affordable for a household earning the median income of
$57,500. The median home price for the region was $391,000. By the third
quarter of 2008, however, the percentage of homes affordable to
households earning median income increased to 48.4 percent. This increase
was largely due to the fact that the median home price dropped to
$220,000, while the median family income saw a modest increase to
$62,000.
Vacancy
Housing vacancy rates - the number of vacant units compared to the total
number of units - reveal the housing supply and demand for a city. Some
amount of housing vacancy is normal to allow for moving time and changing
locations. In Rialto, the housing vacancy rate has decreased significantly over
the last 15 years, to 3.76 percent (including rentals and owned homes), less
than half its rate in 1990.

According to the 2000 Census, vacancy rates for owner and renter-occupied
units differed. Homeowner vacancy rate was only 2.9 percent, while rental
vacancy rate was 5.6 percent, signifying a tight homeownership market.
Special Needs Groups
Certain segments of the population may have more difficulty finding decent,
affordable housing due to their special needs. In Rialto, these special needs
groups include the elderly, disabled persons, large households, female-
headed households, and homeless.

Elderly
The elderly population (generally defined as those over 65 years of age) has
several concerns: limited and fixed incomes, high health care costs, transit
dependency, and living alone. Specific housing needs of the elderly include
affordable housing, supportive housing (such as intermediate care facilities),
group homes, and other housing that includes a planned service component.
The Census estimates that Rialto’s elderly population has decreased in recent
years. In 1990, Rialto’s elderly composed 6.6% of the population, 6.4% of
the population in 2000, and 4.6% of the population in 2005.
Many elderly persons have limited income potential, as they are most often
retired and have fixed income (retirement funds and Social Security Income).
The elderly population in 2005 had a median income of $29,977, according
to the American Community Survey, which is considered low income by
   Page         Chapter
   6-26             6

                                                           HOUSING ELEMENT
HCD. The 2004 CHAS report revealed that more than one-third of seniors
paid more than 30 percent of their income on housing, experiencing a
housing cost burden. While the vast majority of seniors are homeowners, the
percentage of renter seniors who overpaid was much higher than the
average; more than half of senior renters overpay for housing.
In 2000, over two-thirds of the elderly population was disabled. Despite the
large number of seniors who have disabilities, nearly 40 percent live alone,
according to the U.S. Census. However, the majority of elderly in Rialto own
their home, estimated at 87 percent in 2005, an increase of eight percent
from 2000.
                                                      Rent
                         Rent                         13%

                                   Own                      Own
                                   79%                       87%
                                                                       
                Source: U.S. Census 2000, American Community Survey 2005
                        Exhibit 6.10 – Elderly Tenure 2000 and 2005 
Programs including assisted care, shared housing, and housing rehabilitation
assistance can help seniors live comfortably. There are 10 assisted living care
centers for seniors in Rialto, with the capacity to serve 115 residents. For
senior homeowners, Rialto contracts with the Old Timers Foundation to
provide a Senior Minor Home Repair Program to residents over 60 years of
age. This successful program provides grants (usually between $150 and
$250) to low-income seniors and disabled persons. These home repair grants
can help pay for architectural design features that help accommodate
physical disabilities and make a home safer for seniors. During fiscal year
2005/2006, 129 low-income households received grants.
Large Households
In general, large households (with five or more members) are identified as a
group with special housing needs based on the limited availability of
adequately sized, affordable housing units. Large households, when of lower
income, often find themselves living in overcrowded, smaller dwelling units
which in turn, can accelerate unit deterioration. The 2000 Census estimates
that nearly a third of Rialto households (31 percent) are large households.
The 2005 American Community Survey revealed a slight decrease in percent
of large households, to 29 percent.
                                                                                Chapter Page
                                                                                   6    6-27

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
The existing housing stock in Rialto provides large families with a variety of
options. The 2000 Census estimated that over 62 percent of the housing
units in Rialto contained three or more bedrooms. The majority of these
units are owner occupied (84 percent). Correspondingly, the majority of
large families are home owners: 71 percent in 2000 and 77 percent in 2005.
Because of the large number of large units, the existing housing stock likely
could meet the needs of the City’s large families, although affordability (both
price and availability of mortgage financing) issues may limit the accessibility
of these units to many low-income large families.
Female-headed households
Single-parent households require special consideration and assistance
because of the greater need for day care, health care, and support. Female-
headed households with children in particular tend to have lower incomes,
thus limiting housing availability for this group. The 2000 Census revealed
that of the 3,712 female-headed households with children under 18 in Rialto,
nearly 30 percent were living in poverty. As described previously in the
income section, female-headed households with children had a median
income of $22,474, classified as very low-income, earning only 38 percent of
the area median income for a family of four.
Disabled residents
Both mentally and physically disabled residents face housing access and
safety challenges. Disabled persons may face difficulty in finding accessible
housing (housing that is made accessible to people with disabilities through
the positioning of appliances and fixtures, the heights of installations and
cabinets, layout of unit to facilitate wheelchair movement, etc.).
In Rialto, nearly 20 percent of residents were identified as disabled in the
2000 Census. The age group in which disabilities are most common is
seniors above age 65. However, the age group of 16 to 64 also has a sizable
portion of the population with a disability. This age group is especially
important as it almost entirely encompasses the working population, and
disabilities may often affect a person’s ability to work consistently and
regularly.
   Page      Chapter
   6-28           6

                                                             HOUSING ELEMENT
                                   Table 6‐15 
                           Disabled Persons by Age 
                                           Percent of Persons

                 Source: U.S. Census 2000
The U.S. Census defines and estimates the number of persons with six
categories of disabilities:
        Sensory disability: blindness, deafness, or a severe vision or hearing
         impairment
        Physical disability: a condition that substantially limits one or more
         basic physical activities such as walking, climbing stairs, reaching,
         lifting, or carrying
        Mental disability: a physical, mental, or emotional condition lasting
         six months or more that made it difficult to perform activities such as
         learning, remembering, or concentrating
        Self-care disability: a physical, mental, or emotional condition lasting
         six months or more that made it difficult to perform certain activities
         such as dressing, bathing, or getting around inside the home
        Going-outside-the-home disability (also known as mobility
         disability): a physical, mental, or emotional condition lasting six
         months or more that made it difficult to go outside the home alone
         to shop or visit a doctor’s office (tallied only for residents over 16
         years of age)
        Employment disability (also known as work disability): a physical,
         mental, or emotional condition lasting six months or more that made
         it difficult to work at a job or business (tallied only for residents
         between 16 and 64 years of age)
In Rialto, the most common disability is an employment disability,
accounting for 26 percent of total disabilities. Going-outside-the-home-
disability was the second-most common disability, revealing limited mobility
for nearly a quarter of people with disabilities. Many people with disabilities
have multiple disabilities that often fall into separate categories. Because of
this, disabled persons must often consider a variety of complex factors when
attempting to find adequate housing.

community care facilities serving six or fewer persons be permitted by right

Farmworkers
The 2000 Census revealed 81 Rialto residents to have occupations in the
farming, forestry, and fishing industries. These residents are most likely
employed by gardening and landscaping companies, with only 16 individuals
actually working in farming. The low number of farmworkers is due to the
lack of farming-related land uses in the region. As such, the City does not
have a need for farmworker-specific housing. The City allows affordable
   Page           Chapter
   6-30                6

                                                           HOUSING ELEMENT
housing in all residential zones; therefore, affordable housing needs of
people within the “Farming, Forestry, and Fishing” occupations can be
accommodated.
Homeless
Homelessness can be triggered by a variety of factors, including mental
illness, family violence, severe and sudden economic burdens, and housing
costs. In 2003, the Community Action Partnership (CAP) of San Bernardino
County published the results of a daily canvass of the County to assess the
number of homeless persons on the streets and in emergency shelters. The
San Bernardino County 2003 Homeless Census and Survey estimated the
point in time (daily) number of homeless residents in San Bernardino County
to be 5,270 persons. A 1990 Census one-night survey documented only ten
homeless people in emergency shelters and one homeless person visible on
the street in Rialto. The CAP homeless census revealed a much larger
number: 237 homeless persons. Thirty-three (33) people were a part of
homeless families and 26 were youth. The majority of the homeless
population was living on the street, with only five people staying at
emergency or miscellaneous shelters. Areas that tend to attract homeless
people include the Downtown area, the area near the railroad tracks, and
along the freeway interchanges.
                                   Table 6‐18 
                Point‐in‐Time Number of Homeless in Rialto 
         Homeless Individuals                       Homeless Families 
Adult Male                  145          Adult Male                  9
Adult Female                 48          Adult Female                9
Youth                        11          Youth                      15
Individual Total            204          Family Total                33
         Combined Family and Individual Homeless                    237
Source: San Bernardino County 2003 Homeless Census and Survey
Another sector of homeless that is much less visible than those in shelters
and on the streets is the informal homeless sector. These people are much
harder to enumerate, as they stay with friends and relatives, in motels, and
other informal housing arrangements. It is likely that an even larger number
of individuals and families fall into this category, but estimates are
unavailable.
Rialto participates in the San Bernardino County Continuum of Care Plan,
which helps bring homeless people into shelters, provides supportive
services, and helps in the transition to permanent housing. Most of the
homeless shelters in San Bernardino County are located in or near the city of
San Bernardino.

Assisted Housing At-Risk of Conversion
Several affordable housing options in Rialto are funded by federal, local, and
nonprofit sources. Over the next 10 years (2008-2018), a number of assisted
developments that provide a total of 301 affordable units have expiring
affordability covenants (Table 6-19). Affordability covenants include
restrictions placed on developments financed with County Mortgage
Revenue Bonds, redevelopment set-aside funds, State low-income housing
tax credits, and federal programs, including HOME, HUD Section 8, and
HUD 202.

Two affordable housing developments were recently converted to market-
rate housing. The Casa Rialto at 298 Spruce Avenue was converted from 94
affordable units to market rate as the property’s loans matured; the
development no longer accepts Section 8 vouchers. In 2004, the owner of
the Quail Point Apartments at 1651 Riverside Avenue prepaid the County
Mortgage Revenue Bonds early, releasing the property owner from an
   Page         Chapter
   6-32              6

                                                        HOUSING ELEMENT
affordability covenant. The property had 38 affordable units as part of a 192-
unit development, all of which converted to market rate.
Project-based Section 8 developments receive federal subsidies that provide
the owners of these units with the difference between 30 percent of the
tenant’s income and a HUD-established rent for the units. Rialto has three
Section 8 housing developments with a total of 268 units. The California
Housing Partnership Corporation indicates that all of these developments -
Southpointe Villa, Willow Village, and the new TELACU senior housing
development - have Section 8 contracts that expire before 2018.
Both the Southpointe Villa and Willow Village projects are owned by profit-
motivated companies, and are as such may be considered at risk of
conversion to market rate. However, as rental rates and fair market rents in
Rialto are comparable, the risk of conversion is lower because there is less
incentive to convert to market rate because the gain will be nominal. For
example, an average two-bedroom apartment in Rialto rents for $989 per
month. The fair market rate is only $15 per month less than that, at $974 per
month. For three-bedrooms, the risk of conversion decreases even further, as
average rents are actually lower than the fair market rent of $1,383 per
month. Furthermore, HUD offers funding priority for extending Section 8
assistance to housing for seniors and persons with disabilities. The City will
continue to monitor the status of these at-risk units. Should a Notice of Intent
to opt out of the Section 8 program be filed, tenants will be properly notified
of their rights under California law. In addition, both Southpointe Villa and
Willow Village Section 8 contracts have expired in the past, and they have
both opted to remain in the HUD Section 8 program. The TELACU senior
housing project has an affordability covenant ensuring that the property
remains affordable for 55 years based on the Redevelopment Agency
agreement. Further, the property is owned and operated by a non-profit
organization, further lowering the risk that it would be converted to market
rate at a later date.
The Green Tree Senior Apartments are also held by a profit-motivated
owner. However, the rehabilitation of these 272 units was funded partially
with Low Income Housing Tax Credits, which places an affordability
restriction on the 270 affordable units for a period of 55 years.
State, County, and local governments have the authority to issue tax-exempt
mortgage revenue bonds, which result in financing that is approximately two
percent below conventional interest financing rates. State and federal law
require that multi-family projects built with tax-exempt bond proceeds
establish a portion of units as affordable to lower-income households for a
specified period of time. The typical contractual period is 10 to 15 years.
After the term expires, the property owners may rent the units at market
rates. Two projects in the City were financed through County Mortgage
                                                                                 Chapter Page
                                                                                    6    6-33

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Revenue Bonds and remain affordable: Heritage Park Rialto and Orchard
Heights (formerly known as Meadowland Apartments). However, the
original contractual period has expired for both of these projects, and they
may prepay the bonds at any time to release the affordability requirement.
Rialto has four affordable developments that are held by non-profits, as
indicated in the above table. The likelihood of conversion is much lower for
these units. Long-term affordability is fairly secure for these projects as this is
consistent with the nonprofits’ missions to provide affordable housing for the
elderly and low-income families.
Preservation and Replacement Options
Preservation of at-risk projects can be achieved in a variety of ways, with
adequate funding availability. These include:
        Transfer of ownership to nonprofit developers and housing
         organizations
        Providing rental assistance to renters through other funding sources
        Purchase affordability covenants
        Refinance mortgage revenue bonds
Alternatively, units that are converted to market rate may be replaced with
new assisted multi-family units with specified affordability timeframes.
Transfer of Ownership
Transferring ownership of the affordable units to a nonprofit housing
organization is a viable way to preserve affordable housing for the long term
and increases the amount of government resources available to the project.
The feasibility of this option depends on the willingness of the owner to sell,
funding sources to actually buy the property, and the existence of a
nonprofit organization with sufficient administrative capacity to manage the
property. Additionally, projects in which all units are affordable, and not just
a portion of units are affordable, can participate in ownership transfers more
simply and are therefore more likely to be feasible.
In Rialto, the estimated market value for the 301 affordable units in the at-
risk projects is evaluated in Table 6-20. The current market value for all
affordable at-risk units is estimated to be over $10 million.

Rental Assistance
State, local, or other funding sources can be used to provide rental subsidies
to maintain the affordability of at-risk projects. These subsidies can be
structured to mirror the Section 8 program, whereby the subsidy covers the
cost of the unit above what is determined to be affordable for the tenant’s
household income (including a utility allowance) up to the fair market value
of the apartment. Given the mix of unit sizes of the at-risk developments, the
total annual subsidy to maintain the 301 at-risk units is estimated at over
$1.5 million.

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Purchase Affordability Covenants
Another option to preserve the affordability of at-risk projects is to provide
an incentive package to the owners to maintain the projects as low-income
housing. Incentives could include writing down the interest rate on the
remaining loan balance and/or supplementing the Section 8 subsidy
received to market levels. The feasibility of this option depends on whether
the complexes require rehabilitation or are too highly leveraged. By
providing lump-sum financial incentives or on-going subsidies in rents or
reduced mortgage interest rates to the owner, the City can ensure that some
or all of the units remain affordable.
Refinance County Mortgage Revenue Bonds
When County Mortgage Revenue Bonds are refinanced, property owners
are required by the 1986 Tax Reform Act to commit their 20 percent low-
income units for 15 years or as long as the bonds are outstanding, whichever
is greater. Because these bonds are County-managed bonds, the City is
somewhat limited in its ability to effect this option. However, the City can
encourage the County to negotiate with the project owners to refinance the
bonds. The cost to the County to negotiate the bond includes the difference
in interest rates on the remaining debt between the previous and re-
negotiated bonds, an issuance cost of three percent of the bond to be paid
by the County up front, and administrative costs.
Construction of Replacement Units
The construction of new low-income housing can be a means to replace at-
risk units. The cost of developing new housing depends on a variety of
factors, including density, size of units, construction quality and type,
location, and land cost. Assuming a development cost of $150,000 for a
multi-family rental unit, the cost of replacing all 301 affordable at-risk units
would be approximately $45 million.
Estimates of Housing Need
Several factors influence the degree of demand, or "need," for housing in
Rialto. The four major needs categories considered in this element include:
        Housing needs resulting from population growth, both in the City
         and the surrounding region
        Housing needs resulting from the overcrowding of units
        Housing needs that result when households pay more than they can
         afford for housing
        Housing needs of "special needs groups" such as elderly, large
         families, female-headed households, households with a disabled
         person, farmworkers, and the homeless

Projected Housing Need
HCD determined that the projected housing need for the Southern
California region (including the counties of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside,
San Bernardino, Ventura, and Imperial) was 504,758 new housing units.
SCAG allocated this projected growth to the various cities and
unincorporated county areas within the SCAG region, creating the Regional
Housing Needs Assessment (RHNA). The RHNA is divided into four
categories: very low-, low-, moderate-, and above-moderate income. As
determined by SCAG, the City of Rialto’s fair share allocation is 4,323 new
housing units during this planning cycle. The 2007 Rialto RHNA allocation is
nearly twice that of the previous cycle (2,199), reflecting increased growth in
the San Bernardino County region.

Constraints on Housing Development and Maintenance
The City of Rialto is committed to creating adequate and affordable housing
opportunities for all income levels. However, certain governmental, market,
infrastructure, and environmental factors may make it difficult to produce
decent housing. State law requires that cities analyze potential and actual
governmental and non-governmental constraints to the production,
maintenance, and improvement of housing for all persons of all income
levels and disabilities. Should constraints preclude the achievement of
housing goals, State Housing Element law requires jurisdictions to address
and, where appropriate and legally possible, remove governmental
constraints to the maintenance, improvement, and development of housing.
The constraints analysis must also demonstrate local efforts to remove
barriers to development of housing for persons with disabilities.
Market Constraints
Many factors affecting housing costs are related to the larger housing
market. Land costs, construction costs, and labor costs all contribute to the
cost of housing, and can hinder the production of affordable housing.
Additionally, the availability of financing can limit access to homeownership
for some low-income households. The market impacts discussed in this
section are prevalent throughout the region and as such, these factors do
not represent unique or unusual constraints. Nonetheless, the City strives to
encourage and facilitate new home purchases and maintenance of housing
through homebuyer assistance programs and homeowner rehabilitation
programs.
5
  While SCAG data is not represented this way, State law assumes that 50 percent of the very
low-income category is represented by households of extremely low income (less than 30
percent of the MFI).
   Page        Chapter
   6-38              6

                                                        HOUSING ELEMENT
Development Costs
Development costs can severely affect development of potential affordable
housing developments. Limited supply, combined with a high demand,
keeps land costs relatively high throughout Southern California.
Construction costs vary widely according to the type of development, with
multi-family housing generally less expensive to construct than single-family
homes. However, there is wide variation within each construction type,
depending on the size of the unit and the number and quality of amenities
provided.
An indicator of construction costs is Building Valuation Data compiled by the
International Code Council (ICC). The unit costs compiled by the ICC
include structural, electrical, plumbing, and mechanical work, in addition to
interior finish and normal site preparation. The data are national and do not
take into account regional differences nor include the price of the land upon
which the building is built. The national averages for costs per square foot
unit of apartments and single-family homes are as follows:
        Type I or II, Multi-Family: $111.73 to $126.43 per sq. ft.
        Type V Wood Frame, Multi-Family: $86.28 to $90.83 per sq. ft.
        Type V Wood Frame, One and Two Family Dwelling: $94.06 to
         $99.79 per sq. ft.
The unit costs for residential care facilities generally range between $109
and $150 per square foot. These costs are exclusive of the costs of land and
soft costs, such as entitlements, financing, etc.
Another factor related to construction costs is development density. With an
increase in the number of units built in a project, overall costs generally
decrease as builders can benefit from the economies of scale.
The price of land is also one of the largest components of housing
development costs. Land costs may vary depending on whether the site is
vacant or has an existing use that must be removed. Similarly, site constraints
such as environmental issues (steep slopes, soil stability, seismic hazards, or
flooding) can also be factored into the cost of land. Local realtors indicate
that residential land in Rialto averages $467,000 per acre. Depending on
location and desirability of the site, costs can range from a low of $221,000
per acre to a high of $691,000 per acre. In addition to assisting developers
in finding properties that are lower priced, the City can support affordable
housing by writing down the cost of land on Agency-owned property in
exchange for affordability controls.

Labor Cost
The California Labor Code applies prevailing wage rates to public works
projects exceeding $1,000 in value. Public works projects include
construction, alteration, installation, demolition, or repair work performed
under contract and paid for in whole or in part out of public funds. State law
exempts affordable housing projects from the prevailing wage requirement if
they are financially assisted with only redevelopment housing set-aside funds.
However, if other public funds are involved, which is often the case,
prevailing wage rates may still apply. While the cost differential in prevailing
and standard wages varies based on the skill level of the occupation,
prevailing wages tend to add to the overall cost of development. In the case
of affordable housing projects, prevailing wage requirements could
effectively reduce the number of affordable units that can be achieved with
public subsidies.
Home Financing
Interest Rates
Interest rates substantially impact home construction, purchase, and
improvement costs. A fluctuation in rates of 2.5 percent can make a drastic
difference in the annual income needed to qualify for a loan. In the recent
past, Rialto has seen interest rates at historically low levels, which has
enabled many households to purchase a home. These rates have risen over
the past few years, and many adjustable rate mortgages have created
situations whereby households are unable to pay new mortgage rates.
However, the Federal Reserve lowered rates in September 2007, and has
continued to lower rates in response to national and international economic
conditions. Even so, the availability and cost of capital required for pre-
development costs for new housing, such as land purchase option money
and project design and entitlement processing, as well as uncertainty in the
larger housing market, remain a deterrent to development of affordable
multi-family housing.
Availability of Financing
The availability of financing affects a person’s ability to purchase or improve
a home; the cost of borrowing money for residential development is
incorporated directly into the sales price or rent. Interest rates are
   Page       Chapter
   6-40           6

                                                           HOUSING ELEMENT
determined by national policies and economic conditions, and there is very
little a local government can do to affect these rates. Some local
jurisdictions, such as Rialto, offer assistance to residents to make home
buying more affordable.
Under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA), lending institutions
must disclose information on the disposition of loan applications by the
income, gender, and race of applicants. This applies to all loan applications
for home purchases and improvements, whether financed at market rate or
through government assistance. HMDA data can be used to evaluate lender
compliance with anti-discrimination laws and other consumer protection
laws. The anti-discrimination laws include the Equal Credit Opportunity Act
(ECOA) and the Fair Housing Act (FHA). These laws prohibit discrimination
in home mortgage lending, among other things, on several bases such as
race, national origin, sex, and, age.
Table 6-25 presents the reason for denial of conventional home loans in
2008 by income of the applicant. The data is for the Riverside-San
Bernardino-Ontario MSA, of which Rialto is a part. The data includes
purchases of one- to four-unit homes, as well as manufactured homes. The
table shows that, as is to be expected, insufficient income is by far the
primary cause of denial for applicants in the lower income categories. The
second most common single cause for applicants with incomes below the
area median is a poor credit history.

General Plan
Following the housing market collapse that began in 2007, banks
significantly tightened requirements on mortgages; essentially eliminating the
riskier subprime lending that had so inflated the market and led to the
collapse in the first place and cutting back even on prime loans. By the
beginning of 2010, however, there were some signs that banks were starting
to loosen lending restrictions slightly. Loan originations were still decreasing,
nevertheless, because of a drop in demand due to wariness on the part of
consumers in the face of widespread job insecurity and a continuing
recession.6
Interest rates fluctuations have also resulted in an increase in the number of
foreclosures for households with sub-prime loans. In many cases, financing
for these homes was made through the sub-prime credit market. Sub-prime
loans are characterized by higher interest rates and fees than prime loans,
and are more likely to include prepayment penalties. The foreclosure
problem has continued to significantly impact the Inland Empire, while
spreading throughout the region and the State. The greatest year-on-year
increases are now being seen in places like Orange and Ventura Counties,
which had previously been less affected by the wave of foreclosures.

Governmental Constraints
Local policies and regulations can affect the price and availability of housing
and in particular, the provision of affordable housing. Land use controls, site
improvement requirements, fees and exactions, permit processing
procedures, and other factors can constrain the maintenance, development,
and improvement of housing. State and Federal regulations, which the City
has no control over, also affect the availability of land for housing and the
cost of producing housing. Regulations related to environmental protection,
building codes, and other topics have significant, often adverse, impacts on
housing cost and availability. While constraints exist at other levels of
government, this section emphasize policies and regulations that can be
mitigated by the City.
Land Use Controls
The Land Use Element sets forth policies for guiding local development.
These policies, together with existing zoning regulations, establish the
amount and distribution of land to be allocated for different uses within the
City. Table 6-27 below details major land use categories, their density levels,
and residential types permitted.
