   6-94            6

                                                       HOUSING ELEMENT
Program 20 – Section 8 Rental Assistance
The Section 8 Rental Assistance program provides rent subsidies to very low-
income households that spend more than 50 percent or their income on
rent. Rental assistance not only addresses housing affordability, but also
addresses overcrowding by allowing families who are “doubling up” to
afford housing. Under the certificate program, prospective renters secure
housing from HUD-registered apartments that accept the certificates. HUD
pays to the landlords the difference between what the tenant can afford to
pay (30 percent of their income) and the fair market rent. Under the voucher
program, a family can choose housing that costs more than the fair market
rent, provided the tenant pays the additional rent. The County Housing
Authority administers the Section 8 program on behalf of the City.
Actions:               Continue subsidy and encourage registration of
                       buildings; provide information and referrals to
                       landlords regarding participation in the Housing
                       Choice Voucher Program.
Timeframe:             Ongoing
Responsible Agency: County Housing Authority
Funding Sources:       Section 8 Certificates/Vouchers
Program 21 – Tenant-Based Rental Assistance
Through the Security Deposit Assistance Program, the County uses HOME
funds to provide financial assistance with required security deposits on rental
housing units and tenant-paid utilities to persons who can afford monthly
rent payments but lack necessary funds to get into and/or, to avoid being
displaced from, decent housing. In addition, the County provides funds to
low- and moderate-income renter households through the Monthly Rent
Subsidies Program, also funded by the County HOME Program.
Actions:               Continue participation and advertise availability,
                       including by maintaining information about the
                       program and a link to the County’s Housing
                       Development Division web page on the City’s
                       website.
Timeframe:             Ongoing
Responsible Agency: San Bernardino County Economic and Community
                       Development Department
Funding Sources:       County HOME Funds

Program 23 – Energy Conservation Density Bonus Program
Rialto encourages energy conservation by offering a density bonus not to
exceed four units per net acre, which may be granted with energy
consumption, according to Title 24 State of California Energy Calculations,
can be reduced as follows: 1) two-unit bonus per net acre for passive solar
design of units for which average energy savings is 35 percent of the allowed
energy consumption, and 2) an additional two unit bonus per net acre for
passive solar design of units for which average energy savings is 50 percent
of the above standard.
Actions:                 Continue to implement the Energy Conservation

Responsible Agency: Planning Department

Removing Governmental Constraints
Factors that pose constraints to the provision of housing include the costs of
developing both ownership and rental housing, which are ultimately passed
to the consumers; the availability and cost of mortgage and rehabilitation
financing; and restrictive zoning or other development regulations. These
factors tend to disproportionately impact lower- and moderate-income
households due to their limited resources for absorbing the costs. The City of
Rialto will, where legally possible, remove governmental constraints affecting
the maintenance, improvement, and development of housing.
   Page       Chapter
   6-96           6

                                                      HOUSING ELEMENT
Goal 6-4:           Alleviate any potential governmental constraints to
                    housing production and affordability.
Policy 6-4.1:       Periodically review City regulations and ordinances to
                    ensure that they do not unduly constrain housing
                    development.
Policy 6-4.2:       Offer financial and/or regulatory incentives where
                    feasible to offset or reduce the costs of developing
                    affordable housing.
Policy 6-4.3:       Provide for timely processing of development projects to
                    minimize project holding costs.
Policy 6-4.4:       Periodically review residential development fees and
                    service fees to ensure that they are appropriately related
                    to and do not constrain the development.
Program 24 – Second Unit Ordinance
In 1994, the City adopted a Second Unit Ordinance to provide additional
affordable housing options in the community. Subject to a Conditional
Development Permit (CDP), these units can provide independent and
affordable housing for low- and moderate-income households.
Actions:                Amend the Zoning Ordinance to provide for a
                        ministerial process for CDP approval. Continue
                        implementation of the Second Unit Ordinance.
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Responsible Agency: Planning Department
Funding Sources:        General Fund

Program 26 – Extremely Low Income and Special Needs
Housing
Extremely low-income households and households with special needs have
limited housing options. Housing types appropriate for these groups include
emergency shelters, transitional housing, supportive housing, and single-
room occupancy (SRO) units. As part of the Governmental Constraints
analysis, the following revisions to the Rialto Zoning Code, as required by
State law, are identified as appropriate to better facilitate the provision of a
variety of housing types:
Actions:
     Amend the Zoning Code to facilitate housing opportunities for
        extremely low-income persons by establishing definitions,
        performance standards, and siting regulations for transitional and
        supportive housing development and single-room occupancy
        developments (SRO).
     Amend the Zoning Code to provide for emergency homeless
        shelters as a permitted use in the I-P zone, and develop objective
        standards to regulate emergency shelters, as provided for in SB2.
        Develop additional written, objective standards for emergency
        shelters to regulate the following, as permitted in SB2:
             The maximum number of beds/persons permitted to be
                served nightly;
             Off-street parking based on demonstrated need, but not to
                exceed parking requirements for other residential or
                commercial uses in the same zone;
             The size/location of exterior and interior onsite waiting and
                client intake areas;
             The provision of onsite management;
             The proximity of other emergency shelters, provided that
                emergency shelters are not required to be more than 300
                feet apart;
             The length of stay;
             Lighting; and
             Security during hours that the emergency shelter is in
                operation.
Timeframe:               Within one year from adoption of General Plan
Responsible Agency: Planning Department
Funding Sources:         General Fund
   Page      Chapter
   6-98           6

Equal Housing Opportunity
To fully meet the community’s housing needs, the City must assure that
housing is accessible to all residents, regardless of race, religion, family
status, age, or physical disability.
Goal 6-5:            Promote equal opportunity for all residents to reside in
                     the housing of their choice.
Policy 6-5.1:        Continue to enforce fair housing laws prohibiting
                     arbitrary discrimination in the building, financing, selling
                     or renting of housing on the basis of race, religion, family
                     status, national origin, disability, or other protected class.
Policy 6-5.2:        Ensure that residents are aware of their rights and
                     responsibilities regarding fair housing.
Policy 6-5.3:        Continue to cooperate with the Inland Mediation Board
                     to enforce fair housing laws, and provide fair housing
                     education services.

Program 28 – Fair Housing Services
The City contracts with Inland Mediation Board to provide fair housing
services for its residents. Services provided by Inland Mediation include
shared housing information for senior residents, counseling and information
on housing discrimination, tenant/landlord dispute resolution, bilingual
housing literature, and testing for housing discrimination. The City will
continue to provide fair housing services through Inland Mediation and/or
other agencies.
Actions:                Continue participation and advertise program
                        availability.
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Responsible Agency: City Recreation and Community Services Department
Funding Sources:        Community Development Block Grants
Program 29 – Reasonable Accommodation Procedure
The Fair Housing Act requires that cities and counties provide reasonable
accommodation to rules, policies, practices, and procedures where such
accommodation may be necessary to afford individuals with disabilities
equal opportunity to housing. The City’s Zoning Code makes special
provisions for the disabled through reduced parking requirements for senior
housing and rest homes. To create a process for making requests for
reasonable accommodation to land use and zoning decisions and
procedures regulating the siting, funding, development and use of housing
for people with disabilities, the City will adopt a reasonable accommodation
procedure either by resolution or included in the Zoning Code, and will
provide information to residents via public counters and the City’s website.
Actions:                Adopt a reasonable accommodation procedure
                        and/or      Zoning     Code     amendment;    provide
                        information to residents via public counters and the
                        City’s website.
Timeframe:              Within one year of adoption of the Housing Element
Responsible Agency: Planning Department
Funding Sources:        Department Budget

                                        OUR ROOTS: CULTURAL AND
                                                    HISTORIC RESOURCES
Introduction
The future of Rialto is linked strongly to its past. The cultural and historical
resources in Rialto remind the community of our foundation and show how
the City has evolved and changed, both physically and socially, over the
years.
Rialto has undertaken efforts to showcase its past. Downtown’s art theme
incorporates orange crate labels that reflect back to a period when the citrus
industry was the economic foundation of the community, providing local
jobs and opportunity for the families that settled in Rialto. In fact, many old-
timers can probably recount stories of working at a citrus packing house or
playing among the orange groves. Today, only one remaining citrus grove
remains: on property along Cactus Avenue, just south of Merrill Avenue.
Although Rialto has changed over the years, simply by uncovering a thin
layer of the urban fabric, we can reveal a story or two about the historic and
cultural heritage of Rialto. This Chapter provides direction for enhancing the
historical resources in Rialto. As Rialto continues to evolve, the policies in
this Chapter will help Rialto reflect and possibly preserve the history that is
still present or yet to be uncovered.
                                                                                  The original Pacific
                                                                                  Electric train depot
                                                                                  building still
                                                                                  stands on Riverside
                                                                                  Avenue in
                                                                                  Downtown Rialto.

Our History and Culture: Providing Context
Rialto has a long and eventful history. Although it would take many pages to
describe the entire story of Rialto, the following captures important defining
times in the City’s history.
In 1500, Serrano Indians occupied the Rialto Bench, the top of the bluff
above the west bank of Lytle Creek between Etiwanda Avenue to Walnut.
The bench protected these first settlers from occasional flooding, but was
close enough to access the resources along the creek. Over the years, many
Indian artifacts have been located along the bench.
                                                                               Citrus groves and
The new town of Rialto was founded with the introduction of the Santa Fe       the citrus industry,
Railroad, connecting San Bernardino to Los Angeles, in 1887. The area          as represented in
began initially as a citrus-growing town with over 2,000 residents. Low land   this citrus crate
prices, soils, and other conditions made it ideal for citrus growing. Citrus   label, are important
groves, eucalyptus tree wind breaks, and the San Gabriel and San               aspects of Rialto’s
Bernardino Mountains provided a gorgeous backdrop to this agrarian area.       history.
In the 1950s, orange groves were replaced by housing subdivisions as Rialto
became one of the fastest growing cities in the region.
   Page       Chapter
    7-2           7

                                        OUR ROOTS: CULTURAL AND
                                                   HISTORIC RESOURCES
The following timeline of events highlights Rialto’s history:
1769:           The King of Spain awarded portions of the area to Spanish
                Dons.
1830:           Mission San Gabriel establishes the Asistencia, an outpost to
                the mission, on the San Bernardino Rancho at Barton Hill.
1832            Paiute Indians attack the San Bernardino Asistencia, killing
and             Christianized     Indians, taking       supplies, and burning
                buildings;
1834:           the San Bernardino Asistencia is abandoned shortly
                thereafter.
1845:           Benjamin Wilson leads an expedition up the Santa Ana River
                Canyon, marking the earliest historically known use of the
                canyon as a transportation route. This attracts trappers and
                expands the fur trade in the San Bernardino Mountains.
1851:           Five hundred Mormons from Salt Lake City settle in the San
                Bernardino Valley near a creek they named Lytle Creek, after
                their leader Captain Andrew Lytle. They claim rights to
                homestead potions above Lytle Creek that would eventually
                become known as the Rialto Bench.
1845-1860s:     Development of the lumber industry and discovery of gold in
                the area’s mountains occur.
1853            Michael White constructs the first house in Rialto; this house
and             stands today at Bud Bender Park as the oldest house in
1854:           Rialto.
1853:           Colonel Henry Washington surveys the California Base Line
                (Base Line Road), which becomes the basis for land titles and
                a major road through the San Bernardino Valley.
1860s-1870s: Rialto’s access to water and frequent winds attract citrus
                farmers.
1887:           The Semi-Tropic Land and Water Company lays out the
                townsite of Rialto on the new Santa Fe Railroad line between
                San Bernardino and Los Angeles.
1887:           A group of Kansas Methodists, headed by the Reverend T. C.
                Miller, arrived in the area looking for a site for a Methodist
                College. They eventually started the town later to be named
                Rialto.
                                                                               Chapter Page
                                                                                  7     7-3

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
1889:         Rialto’s train depot is completed and leads to better access,
              land speculation, and population growth.
Late 1880s:   Construction of the Boom Hotel on Riverside Avenue with a
              replica of Italy’s Rialto Bridge built over the pool, perhaps
              leading to the town’s name.
1888:         First school in Rialto built; the Rialto School District is formed
              in 1891.
1907:         Rialto Chamber of Commerce is established.
1907:         The First Christian Church is constructed on Riverside
              Avenue in the Gothic Revival and Craftsman styles by
              architect H.M. Patterson; it remains the most prominent
              historical architect-designed building in the City.
1911:         Rialto incorporates and become a city.
1913:         Foothill Boulevard becomes part of Route 66 and puts Rialto
              on the transcontinental tourist route.
1914:         The Pacific Electric Railway completes its line through Rialto,
              offering speedy passenger service to San Bernardino and Los
              Angeles.
1920s:        A fire sweeps through the downtown area, destroying many
              businesses.
1937:         The entire length of Route 66 is paved through Rialto.
1946:         Sam Miro establishes Rialto Municipal Airport (Miro Field).
1958:         Rialto’s Eisenhower High School, a “Blue Ribbon School” is
              built
1978:         Eisenhower High School administration building burns down
              and is replaced one year later.
1993:         Metrolink service between Rialto and Los Angeles begins.
1998:         Eisenhower High School is remodeled.
2007:         SR-210 opens between I-15 and I-215.

Historic and Cultural Resources
National Register of Historic Places
First Christian Church of Rialto
Constructed in 1907 and located at 201 North Riverside Avenue, the First
Christian Church building in the late Gothic Revival architectural style was
designed by architect H.M. Patterson of Los Angeles. The church remains the
most prominent historical building in the City.
                                                                              Located at 201 N.
                                                                              Riverside Avenue,
                                                                              the First Christian
                                                                              Church is
                                                                              recognized by the
                                                                              National Register
                                                                              of Historic Places.
                                                                             Chapter      Page
                                                                                7          7-5
CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
California Historical Landmarks and Points of Interest
Grapeland Homesteads and Water Works
In 1890, the Grapeland Irrigation District was formed to capture and utilize
the waters of Lytle Creek, encouraging settlement and fruit farming north of
the Fontana and Rialto areas, formerly known as Grapeland. In the 1880s,
the community of Grapeland, covering approximately 10,600 acres,
consisted of a school, post office, and commercial businesses, as well as
small ranches along Lytle Creek Road. The water works consisted of the
former Sierra Vista Reservoir built by Chinese laborers in 1886 and various
irrigation canals, conduits, and tunnels. See Exhibit 7.1 for Grapeland
Irrigation District boundary.
Agua Mansa Community
Agua Mansa was the home of New Mexican colonists on the Bandini
Donation that was established on the north side of the Santa Ana River,
along a stretch of road constructed by the missionaries of San Gabriel. Agua
Mansa (Gentle Water) was a seemingly ideal settlement location because
the Santa Ana River flowed through the area and the soil was rich. The new
settlers built adobe homes and had their plots of land in the river bottom,
where they planted gardens, orchards, and vineyards. The community also
established a small church and a cemetery.

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
National Old Trails Highway (Route 66)
The National Old Trails Highway, a transcontinental transportation route and
the pre-cursor to Historic Route 66, was completed between 1911 and
1914, and much of the history of San Bernardino County has been made
along this trail. This route was originally a Mojave Indian travel and trade trail
from the Colorado River to the California coast.
San Bernardino County Museum
This was the original site of the San Bernardino County Museum, located at
18860 Orange Avenue in Bloomington. Originally opened to the public in
1957, the museum was started by the San Bernardino County Historical
Society and the San Pedro Pioneer Society in 1951. The former building was
demolished at an unknown date.
Bloomington Garage
The Bloomington Garage, built in 1911, is considered important to the
history of Bloomington. The garage was the first commercial business at the
corner of Cedar Avenue and Valley Boulevard, and opened to serve the new
motoring community of this portion of Southern California during the early
twentieth century. Owned an operated by the LaGue family for 77 years, it is
among the oldest buildings in Bloomington.
                                                                                   Located in Rialto’s
                                                                                   Sphere of Influence,
                                                                                   the Bloomington
                                                                                   Garage, during its
                                                                                   heyday, was the only
                                                                                   gas station between
                                                                                   Ontario and San
                                                                                   Bernardino. Although
                                                                                   moved from its
                                                                                   original location, the
                                                                                   garage still stands
                                                                                   today.

                                   OUR ROOTS: CULTURAL AND
                                              HISTORIC RESOURCES
Goals and Policies
Historical Resources
Goal 7-1:     Preserve Rialto’s significant historical resources as a
              source of community identity, stability, aesthetic
              character, and social value.
Policy 7-1.1: Protect the architectural, historical, agricultural, open
              space, environmental, and archaeological resources in
              Rialto.
Policy 7-1.2: Identify, through appropriate research and surveys, the
              historical resources in Rialto through documentation and
              photography.
Policy 7-1.3: Explore and evaluate different approaches to protect and
              enhance historical resources throughout the community.
Policy 7-1.4: Encourage economically feasible preservation             of
              historical structures through adaptive reuse.
Goal 7-2:     Provide public understanding and involvement of the
              unique heritage of the City of Rialto.
Policy 7-2.1: Heighten the community awareness of Rialto’s history
              and the City’s physical development, and educate the
              public to the significance of historical areas, sites, and
              structures and the social events associated with them.
Policy 7-2.2: Establish, promote, and enhance a Rialto history
              collection centered on the archaeological, historic
              archaeological and historical texts, archives, and
              collections of value to Rialto.
Archaeological Resources
Goal 7-3:     Identify,      document,      and    protect    significant
              archaeological resources in Rialto.
Policy 7-3.1: Require archaeological surveys during the development
              review process for all projects in archaeologically
              sensitive areas where no previous surveys are recorded.
Policy 7-3.2: Actively pursue a comprehensive survey program to
              identify, document, and protect prehistoric and historical
                                                                          Chapter Page
                                                                             7     7-9

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
                   archaeological sites and sites containing Native American
                   human remains.
Policy 7-3.3:      Avoid impacts to potentially significant prehistoric and
                   historical archaeological resources and sites containing
                   Native American human remains consistent with State
                   law.
Policy 7-3.4:      Reduce adverse impacts to significant archaeological
                   resources that can not be protected in place through data
                   recovery excavations.

                                               IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
Introduction
This Implementation Plan will guide City elected officials, Commissions and Committees, staff, and
the public in efforts to put into practice the adopted General Plan goals and policies. The purpose
of the Implementation Plan is to translate the direction set forth in the General Plan and the Guiding
Principles from general terms to specific actions.
Each implementation measure is a procedure, program, or technique that requires City action,
either alone or in collaboration with non-City organizations or State and federal agencies. Some of
the implementation measures are processes or procedures that the City currently administers on a
day-to-day basis (such as development project review), while others identify new programs or
projects. Completion of the identified measures will be subject to funding availability.
The implementation measures are organized by General Plan elements:
               Managing the Land Supply: Land Use, Open Space, Community Design, and
                Conservation
               Investing in the Future: Economic Development, Redevelopment, Infrastructure, and
                Public Services and Facilities
               Making the Connections: Circulation
               Creating Great Neighborhoods: Safety and Noise
               Where We Live: Housing
               Our Roots: Cultural and Historical Resources
Each implementation measure relates directly to one or more General Plan policy, drawn from
various elements. For each program, the related General Plan policies are listed, along with the
responsible agencies or City departments, the recommended time frame, and likely funding source.
The measures are not grouped by element, as the measures can relate to policies in more than one
element.
This Implementation Plan is intended for use as the basis for preparing the Annual Report to the
City Council on the status of the City’s progress in implementing the General Plan, as described in
Section 65400 of the Government Code. Because many of the individual actions and programs act
as mitigation for environmental impacts resulting from planned development pursuant to the
General Plan, the annual report can also provide a means of monitoring application of the
mitigation measures as required by Public Resources Code Section 21081.6. The programs should
be updated concurrent with the budget process and whenever the City’s General Plan is amended
or updated to provide continued consistency and usefulness.
Key to Time Frames:
    Short-term = 0-5 years
    Mid-term = 5-10 years
    Long-term = 10-20 years
    On-going = May require short-, mid-, and long-term actions

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Managing the Land Supply: Land Use, Open Space, Community Design,
and Conservation
Measure 8.1: Annual Review of General Plan, Land Use Policy Map, and Environmental
Indicators
Annually review implementation of the General Plan and Land Use Map to identify the effect of
land development, and evaluate programs and services. Develop a range of environmental
indicators to be monitored over time as the community develops. Such indicators may include, but
are not limited to, the following: ratio of parkland/population, amount of new housing created,
percentage of solid waste diverted from the waste stream through recycling, etc. Utilize the City’s
GIS system to create and track these indicators, and report annually to the City Council regarding
the progress toward established objectives.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Ongoing (Annually)
Related Policies:        2.1-1 to 2-9.4
Measure 8.2: Zoning Code Revisions to Create New Districts
Update the Zoning Ordinance upon adoption of the General Plan. The update will create zoning
districts as needed to implement the Managing the Land Supply: Land Use, Open Space,
Community Design, and Conservation. Specific development standards will be established for each
newly created zoning district. Revise density ranges and non-residential floor-area ratios to
correspond to new General Plan categories.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        2.1-1 to 2-9.4
Measure 8.3: Zone Changes to Correct Inconsistencies
Initiate zone changes for properties where zoning designations are not consistent with General Plan
designations. These changes of zones will include, but not be limited to, the following:
        Properties identified in the Housing Element as potential sites for affordable housing
        Properties where the General Plan designation has been changed to Mixed Use
        Other properties where the General Plan designations have changed and the existing
         zoning is not consistent with the new General Plan designations
Agency/Department: Development Services
Funding Source:
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        2.1-1 to 2-9.4
   Page      Chapter
     8-2          8

                                                  IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
Measure 8.4: Development of Specific Plans
Utilize the Specific Plan process for planning in established areas of Rialto which may undergo land
use transformation, including mixed use opportunities at major in-fill sites and along major corridors
(e.g., Foothill Boulevard).
Work with property owners in the development of Specific Plans consistent with State law, or other
comprehensive planning tools satisfactory to the City, to establish permitted densities, intensities,
and uses for areas designated as requiring specific plans in the General Plan and other areas where
specific plans would provide for the systematic implementation of the General Plan. The Land Use
Plan requires the development of specific plans for the following areas:
        Agua Mansa Specific Plan
        Central Area Specific Plan
        Lytle Creek Specific Plan
        Renaissance Rialto Specific Plan
        Foothill Boulevard Specific Plan
        Gateway Specific Plan
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment and Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund, Developer Fees
Time Frame:              Mid-term
Related Policies:        2-1.2, 2-1.2, 2-1.3, 2-1.4, 2-4.1, 2-4.2
Measure 8.5: Corridors Revitalization
Assess existing development opportunities along the Riverside Avenue and Valley Boulevard
corridors to determine where enhancements can be programmed into new development or
redevelopment in the future.
        Riverside Avenue Corridor
        Valley Boulevard Corridor
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Mid-term
Related Policies:        2-2.1 to 2-3.3
Measure 8.6: Explore Development Opportunities
Continue to explore development opportunities by marketing the following sites that have the
potential for retail development:
        Gateway Project Area Opportunities
        SR-210 Freeway Corridor
        Renaissance Rialto Retail
        Foothill Boulevard Sites

Measure 8.7: Downtown
Implement the Rialto Downtown Vision and Strategic Plan and the identified changes identified in
the Land Use Policy Map.
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment and Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Mid-term
Related Policies:        2-5.1 to 2-5.9
Measure 8.8: Transit-Oriented Design Features in Downtown
Develop a Transit Center/ Park and Ride facility in the City in conjunction with a commuter rail
station. This Transit Center/Park and Ride facility should include a bus staging area with concrete
pads and a sheltered waiting area. Vehicles using this depot would include public transit vehicles,
dial-a-ride services, and the City shopper van. The park and ride lot would be directly adjacent to
the transit area and would offer parking and rendezvous points for carpool and vanpool
participants. Installation of bicycle racks. Parking lot configuration should be designed to provide
incentives for carpools and vanpools. Provide adequate sidewalks and access ways to encourage
and facilitate pedestrian uses.
Require incorporation of transit-oriented design features and attractive and appropriate transit
amenities (including shaded bus stops) into public and private development projects, as
appropriate, to promote and support public transit use.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          Transportation Development Act, Development Fees
Time Frame:              Mid-term
Related Policies:        2-5.2
Measure 8.9: Prepare Citywide Design Guidelines and Standards
Develop citywide design guidelines and standards which address all architectural and landscaping
aspects identified in the General Plan under policies 2-10.1 to 2-22.3. Consider establishing a master
sign programs for all commercial and industrial centers in the citywide design guidelines.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        2-10.1 to 2-23.3

Measure 8.10: City Gateways
Work with the Architectural Commission and Community Services Commission to create plans for
and installation of strong, unifying gateways with signage and other public improvements that have
design components that communicate Rialto’s identity and character at major entrances to the City
on Foothill Boulevard, Base Line Road, Indian Hill Boulevard, and Arrow Highway.
Agency/Department:       Public Works and Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Mid-term
Related Policies:        2-10.1 to 2-10.3
Measure 8.11: Code Enforcement
Continue to enforce property maintenance standards, noise regulations, and other property-related
regulatory standards in the adopted City Building Code, Zoning Code, Municipal Code, and other
City ordinances in efforts to keep properties throughout the City well maintained, and to prevent
neglect of buildings that are vacant due to foreclosures.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        2-3.3, 2-8.2
Measure 8.12: Annexation of Unincorporated Areas
Educate residents living in unincorporated areas within Rialto’s Sphere of Influence on the
cost/benefits of annexation. Prepare informational handouts to give to residents in the
unincorporated areas,
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Short-Term
Related Policies:        2-7.1 to 2-7.4
Measure 8.13: Open Space Easements
Utilize open space easements and other regulatory techniques to avoid public safety hazards on
properties identified as having active fault zones, geologic hazards, flooding hazards, and wildland
fire conditions that pose substantial constraints on development within the Lytle Creek area. Utilize
similar techniques for public utility corridors and transmission lines. As part of the development
review process, the City will require that all such features be clearly delineated on site plans and
subdivision maps. The approach used to avoid or mitigate the hazards will be crafted to meet the
specific conditions on the site, and project and/or map conditions of approval will include language
defining the restrictions.
Agency/Department: Development Services
Funding Source:          Development Fees; Private and Public Development
Time Frame:              Ongoing

Measure 8.14: Urban Open Space
Require project proponents to incorporate plazas, courtyards, mini-parks, recreational areas,

types of development proposed.
Agency/Department:       Development Services

Measure 8.15: Parks and Recreation Services Master Plan
Develop a Park and Recreation Services Master Plan that will achieve a 3.0 acres of parks per 1,000
persons, and continue to provide high-quality recreation services and programs. The plan should
include, but not limited to community input, deficiency analysis, demand analysis, maintenance
section, sustainable parks section, recreation program and services, and implementation and
funding section.
Agency/Department:       Development Services and Recreation and Community Services
Funding Source:          Park Development Fees; Grants; CDBG; General Fund; Quimby fees
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        2-27.1 to 2-27.3
Measure 8.16: Water Conservation Programs and Education
Collaborate with local water provides to explore the feasibility and costs/benefits of potential
programs/incentives to encourage water conservation in the community. Continue to investigate
and implement programs to reduce water usage at City parks and facilities. Educate residents about
landscape design and the advantage of using drought-tolerant plants. Encourage the use of drought-
tolerant plants and irrigation techniques that will result in water conservation.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              On-going
Related Policies:        2-29.1 to 2-29.3
Measure 8.17: National Pollutant Discharge and Elimination System (NPDES) Compliance
Continue to comply with all provisions of the National Pollutant Discharge and Elimination System
(NPDES) permit, and support regional efforts by SARWQCB to improve and protect water quality.
Estimate increases in pollutant loads and flows resulting from projected future development projects
utilizing available methods prior to making land use decisions on such projects. In addition, require
applicants for new development and redevelopment projects to demonstrate accomplishment of
the following NPDES objectives:
   Page       Chapter
     8-6           8
                                                 IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
        Use of structural and non-structural Best Management Practices (BMPs) to mitigate
         projected increases in pollutant loads and flows.
        Minimize pollutant loading flow velocity during and after construction.
        Minimize amounts of impervious surfaces and directly connected impervious surfaces.
        Maximize on-site infiltration and runoff, and temporary on-site retention areas.
        Limit disturbance of natural water bodies and natural drainage systems.
        Employ pollution prevention methods, source controls, and treatment using small collection
         strategies located at, or as close as possible to, the source.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          Development Fees; Private Development
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        2-28.2, 2-28.4, 2-28.6, 2-28.8

Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        2-30.1 to 2-31.33

Measure 8.21: Reclamation of Mined Areas
Monitor all mineral extraction activity for compliance with requirements of the California
Environmental Quality Act, and consistency with the California Surface Mining and Reclamation
Act.
Monitor management of mineral extraction activities to reduce direct and indirect negative impacts
on the City. Compile and maintain maps and descriptions of potential mineral resources as a basis
for land use policy and regulation and compatibility with State designated mineral resource sectors.
Work with property owners to reclaim lands mined prior to the Surface Mining and Reclamation
Act of 1975 (SMARA) to a beneficial end use.
Agency/Department:      Public Works and Development Services
Funding Source:         General Fund
Time Frame:             Ongoing
Related Policies:       2-32.1 to 2-33.2
Measure 8.22: California Department of Conservation, Office of Mine Reclamation
Work with the Office of Mine Reclamation to ensure mine               operators’ compliance with the
requirements set forth in the Surface Mining and Reclamation            Act of 1975 (SMARA), and for
reclamation planning that promotes cost-effective reclamation           for any new mining proposals
approved by the City. Work with property owners to reclaim             lands previously mined prior to
SMARA to a beneficial end use.
Agency/Department:      Public Works and Development Services
Funding Source:         General Fund
Time Frame:             Ongoing
Related Policies:       2-32.1 to 2-33.2
Measure 8.23: Air Quality Analysis
Review future development proposals for potential regional and local air quality impacts per CEQA.
If potential impacts are identified, mitigation will be required to reduce the impact to a level less
than significant, where technically and economically feasible.
Agency/Department:      Development Services
Funding Source:         Development fees; private development
Time Frame:             On-going
Related Policy:         2-36.1 to 2-37.3
Measure 8.24: South Coast Air Quality Management District
Continue to work with the South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) and the
Southern California Association of Governments (SCAG) to implement the Air Quality Management
Plan, and federal and State air quality standards for pollutants. Participate in any future amendments
and updates to the Plan. Implement and interpret the General Plan in a manner consistent with the
Air Quality Management Plan.

Measure 8.25: Control of Dust During Construction
Require the following measures to be taken during the construction of all projects to reduce the
amount of dust and other sources of particulate matter (PM), in accordance with SCAQMD Rules:
        Dust suppression at construction sites using surfactants and other chemical stabilizers
        Wheel washers for construction equipment
        Watering down of all construction areas
        Limit speeds at construction sties to 15 miles per hour
        Covering of aggregate or similar material during transportation of material
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          Development Fees; Private Development
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        2-35.1 to 2-37.3
Measure 8.26: Ecological and Biological Resource Assessments
Require environmental review of individual development applications pursuant to the California
Environmental Quality Act (CEQA.). The City will require that such review assess potential impact to
sensitive ecological and biological resources. As a first approach to protecting resources, the City
will look for development approaches that avoid sensitive habitat and wildlife corridors. Where
avoidance is not possible, the City will require habitat enhancement or restoration, off-site
mitigation at ratios acceptable to permitting agencies, or any combination of these approaches.
All mitigation shall meet the requirements of any applicable resource conservation or protection
plans in place at the time a development is proposed, and shall include comprehensive mitigation
satisfactory to the City and any and all responsible permitting agencies.
Agency/Department:       Development Services,
Funding Source:          Development Fees
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        2-38.1 to 2-38.2
Measure 8.27: California Fish and Game and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Continue to coordinate with State and federal wildlife agencies in efforts to protect rare or
endangered species of plants and animals, and require that development activities adhere to State
and federal legislation protecting sensitive plants and animals.
Agency/Department:       Development Services
Funding Source:          General Fund; Development Fees
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        2-38.3

Measure 8.28: Redevelopment Agency Five-Year Implementation Plan
Continue to implement and update the Redevelopment Agency’s Five-Year Implementation Plan
according the requirements set forth in AB 1290 and Section 33490 of the Health and Safety Code

Agency/Department:       Redevelopment
Funding Source:          Redevelopment Agency Funds
Time Frame:              Short-term
Related Policies:        3-3.1 to 3-5.2
Measure 8.29: Business Assistance
Continue to provide business assistance programs, including providing flexible, custom-designed
financing programs to assist Rialto business property owners and tenants with small improvement
projects or expansion of their operations in Rialto. Use program funds to select and assist
businesses wishing to establish operations in Rialto.
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment
Funding Source:          Redevelopment Agency Funds
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        3-1.3, 3-1.7, 3-2.3
Measure 8.30: Commercial Rehabilitation Program for Downtown
Continue to provide the Commercial Rehabilitation Program which provides grants and low interest
rate loans to qualified property owners for façade rehabilitation of commercial buildings within the
Rialto Downtown. The project implements the Downtown Revitalization Goal by encouraging
rehabilitation of commercial structures and attracting new businesses in Downtown.
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment
Funding Source:          CDBG and Redevelopment Agency Funds
Time Frame:              Ongoing
Related Policies:        3-2.1 to 3-2.6
Measure 8.31: Rialto Chamber of Commerce
Continue to work with the Rialto Chamber of Commerce and Village Marketing Group to promote
the local economy, increase tourism, improve economic health of businesses in the community,
addressing parking issues, and revitalize aging commercial centers. Actively promote inclusion of
the Rialto Chamber of Commerce and Village Marketing Group in the economic development
activity of the City, and establish communication with Chamber leadership to advance and sustain a
healthy business environment in the City. Continue to support the Village Venture event.

Measure 8.32: Inland Empire Small Business Development Center
The Inland Empire Small Business Development Center (SBDC) is the region’s premier provider of
business consulting and training services for the existing and aspiring business owner. The SBDC
delivers quality consulting, instructive, and relevant training and complete resources to over 5,000
business prospects every year. Support the SBDC’s programs.
Agency/Department:      Redevelopment

Measure 8.37: Monitor Water Quality and Perchlorate Contamination
Continue to provide Rialto with clean, safe, and affordable drinking water. Monitor land uses
draining into water sources and water recharge areas, preventing contaminations from hazardous
substances and landfills. Monitor perchlorate plume within the Rialto-Colton Groundwater Basin.
Continue to monitor all applicable State health goals, standards, and health studies for perchlorate.
Pursue parties that are responsible for the perchlorate pollution to pay for the clean up of the Rialto-
Colton Groundwater Basin. Responsible parties must also pay ratepayers for the costs incurred in
forcing the polluters to clean it up. Continue Rialto’s Zero Tolerance Policy on shutting down water
wells and taking them out of service if they test positive for detectible levels of perchlorate.
Agency/Department:      Public Works
Funding Source:         General Fund
Time Frame:             Ongoing
Related Policies:       3-8.3, 3-8.4
Measure 8.38: City of Rialto Urban Water Management Plan
Continue to implement the City of Rialto Urban Water Management Plan. The Urban Water
Management Plan identifies information on water use and current water conservation measures,
describes water deficiencies, analyzes future projections of water supply needs, defines alternative
water conservation measures, and includes an implementation schedule. The Plan identifies
strategies for water conservation by municipal water agencies and potential capital improvement
projects to expand recycled water.
Agency/Department:      Public Works
Funding Source:         General Fund
Time Frame:             Ongoing
Related Policies:       3-8.1 to 3-8.9
Measure 8.39: Water Conservation

water conservation methods, and other water conservations strategies and standards. Prepare

automobiles and other vehicles through intersections, to reduce congestion on City streets, to assist
drivers in getting to their destinations, and to maintain safe conditions. Striping shall maximize
room for bike lanes where feasible.

report on the need for the improvements and their relationship to the impacts caused by new
development in Rialto. Prepare a resolution to City Council to incorporate the fair share cost of the
improvements that are apportioned to new development into the City’s Transportation Impact Fees.

Measure 8.77: Geologic Hazard Assessments
Require applicants to prepare site-specific geologic and/or geotechnical studies and soils
investigations for proposed new development projects located in areas with expansive soils, or
areas identified as susceptible to landslides and liquefaction. Measures from the studies shall be
incorporated into the site development for subsequent projects to mitigate potential damage to
foundations and structures to the satisfaction of the city engineer and building official. In addition,
applicants may be required to incorporate measures, as appropriate, to stabilize and maintain
slopes on a site-by-site basis. Such measures include, but are not limited to, proper planting,
irrigation, retaining walls, and benching.
Agency/Department:        Development Serviced
Funding Source:           Private and Public Development
Time Frame:               Ongoing
Related Policies:         5-1.1 to 5-1.2

identify needed flood control improvements, and develop funding for improvements as needed.

Measure 8.79: Adequate Flood Control
Require the construction of appropriate flood control facilities for development projects. As needed,
require hydrology studies in accordance with San Bernardino County standards to determine
required flood/storm control facilities for future development projects, and require that
recommendations of the studies be incorporated into the design of projects. Where appropriate,
also require that studies include analysis of instability for natural watercourses that include stream
degradation, head cutting, bank erosion, and related factors, and require recommendations from
the studies to be implemented as mitigation for identified impacts.

Funding Source:           Private and Public Development

Measure 8.86: Emergency Operations Plan
Implement the City’s Emergency Operations Plan (EOP) according to requirements and provisions
of the State Emergency Management System (SEMS) and National Incident Management System
(NIMS). At the time of an emergency, community evacuation routes and emergency shelter facilities
shall be identified based on available safe routes and undamaged buildings.

describes the appropriate actions and responsibilities of personnel designated for participation in
emergency response activities. The emergency response manual shall include a map indicting
clearly the City’s designated evacuation routes and an operating plan for evacuation management
to ensure safe and orderly evacuation. It should also include detailed listings of personnel and
responsibilities in the event of an emergency.

Measure 8.94: Noise Insulation Standards
Implement provisions of the California Noise Insulation Standards (Title 24) that specify that indoor
noise levels for multi-family residential living spaces shall not exceed 45 dB CNEL. The standard is
defined as the combined effect of all noise sources and is implemented when existing or future
exterior noise levels exceed 60 dB CNEL. Title 24 further requires that the standard be applied to all
new hotels, motels, apartment houses, and dwellings other than single-family dwellings. The City will
also apply this standard to single-family dwellings and condominium conversion projects.
Agency/Department:       Development Services,
Funding Source:          Development Fees; Private Development

Where We Live: Housing
Measure 8.96: Home Sweet Home
The Home Sweet Home Program is a deferred loan program which provides up to $8,000 for
single-family property improvements. This home improvement program works in tandem with the
City’s code enforcement activities to focus on specific neighborhoods. Code inspections are made
of each property in the target neighborhoods. Where code violations are cited, below-market-rate
loans are made available to qualified homeowners to help correct the violations. Loan repayment
terms are tailored to the homeowner’s ability to pay. The Home Sweet Home Program is funded
with the City’s Redevelopment Set-Aside funds.
Actions:    Approximately 15 households per year will be assisted through this program.
Agency/Department:      Redevelopment
Funding Sources:        Redevelopment Set-Aside Funds
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:       6-1.1 to 6-1.7
Measure 8.97: Minor Rehabilitation Program
The Minor Rehabilitation Home Repair Program provides home improvement assistance to Rialto
homeowners with an interest free deferred loan of up to $10,000, with an extra $5,000 possible in
cases of serious Health & Safety Code violations. The program also assists first-time homebuyers
with repairs to homes just purchased which will be occupied as the applicant’s primary residence.
With this program there are no equity requirements.
Actions:    The City expects to assist approximately 10 to 15 households per year with this
            program.
Agency/Department:      Redevelopment
Funding Sources:        Redevelopment Set-Aside Funds
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:       6-1.1 to 6-1.7
Measure 8.98: Senior Minor Repair
The Senior Minor Home Repair Services Program is a grant program that assists persons 62 years or
older as well as the disabled. Grants are typically in the amount of $100. The repair work is
conducted by a consultant approved for the program.
Actions:    Assist approximately 140 low- and moderate-income seniors per year.

Measure 8.103: Multi-family Improvement Districts
The City will continue and expand its Multi-family Improvement District program, currently in a pilot
implementation in the East Jackson Street neighborhood. This program, which allows for the
creation of an assessment district by the owners of at least two-thirds of the properties in a
neighborhood, helps to mitigate the negative effects of one or two irresponsible landlords. If an
assessment district is voted into existence, membership fees are collected from every property
owner in the district. Money from these fees can be used for improvements like supplemental
security, landscape maintenance, supplemental code enforcement, parks, benches, and parking.
Actions:     Evaluate the expansion of the program to other neighborhoods beyond East Jackson
             Street. If other neighborhoods are found where this program might be useful, begin a
             process of outreach to landlords in these neighborhoods to convince them to launch a
             Multi-family Improvement District.
Agency/Department: Redevelopment
Funding Sources:          Evaluation to be funded out of Redevelopment Agency operating budget;
                          Districts are expected to pay for themselves within a year or two in savings
                          due to reduced services and increased tax revenue.
Timeframe:                Short-term
Related Policies:         6-1.1 to 6-1.7
Measure 8.104: Citywide Homeowner Association Survey
The City will conduct a citywide survey of homeowner associations to identify and analyze their
strength and health. In addition, the City will evaluate the options for enforcement legislation or
incentive policies that would encourage strong homeowners’ associations.
The strength of the homeowners association is one of the critical factors contributing to the long
term success of a common-interest development. Factors common to effective HOA’s are:
       An active Board of Directors, elected by the residents.
       An approved set of CCR’s and a willingness to enforce them
       Strong on-site property management
       Good potential tenant screening
       Adequate budgeting and reserves to address ongoing expenses and deferred maintenance
                                                                                Chapter       Page
                                                                                   8          8-33

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
Larger multi-family properties which do not have these factors in place are likely to experience
continuing problems, eventually leading to problem tenants, deteriorating appearance, and
diminishing property values. These troubled properties eventually contribute to the decline of the
surrounding neighborhood.
Actions: Conduct citywide survey of homeowners’ associations. Investigate and evaluate regulatory
and incentive-based options to encourage strong homeowners’ associations.
Agency/Department: City Planning Department
Timeframe:              Short-term
Related Policies:       6-1.4
Measure 8.105: Targeted Neighborhood Approach
The major source of housing problems and other societal neighborhood problems in the City of
Rialto is distressed, poorly managed multi-family properties. In addition, the surrounding
neighborhoods where these properties are located need attention as well. To systematically address
these problem neighborhoods, the City will adopt a Targeted Neighborhood approach, focusing a
variety of resources on specific neighborhoods in a concentrated and comprehensive fashion.
The problem neighborhoods in Rialto could further degrade if the housing market continues to
stagnate and/or if the economy worsens. These problem neighborhoods have the following
characteristics:
       Distressed multifamily apartment projects with both property management problems and
        site/maintenance problems
       Physical decline in surrounding single-family properties
       Lack of consistent enforcement of current city codes and ordinances
       Increasing foreclosures in recently purchased ownership housing and refinancing of
        mortgage loans (single-family units and condos), both as a result of aggressive financing
        (described above)
Under the Targeted Neighborhood Approach, the City will first identify and prioritize its problem
neighborhoods. The neighborhood with the greatest need will receive a concentration of resources,
potentially including, but not limited to:
1.  A dedicated code enforcement officer
2.  The creation of Multifamily Improvement Districts in multifamily residential neighborhoods
3.  A preference for rehabilitation loans for landlords to improve the appearance of their properties
4.  A focus of redevelopment funding
5.  The development of Neighborhood Watch and volunteer code enforcement programs
When an area is stabilized with an active group of local residents and landlords taking part in its
further maintenance, the City will move on to target the neighborhood with the next greatest need.
Actions:     1. Identify and prioritize problem neighborhoods
             2. Determine which resources would be most appropriate for the targeted
                 neighborhood
   Page       Chapter
   8-34           8

                                              IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
            3. Determine measurements to be used to measure success of program
            4. Apply resources to targeted neighborhood until desired measurements achieved
            5. Move on to next neighborhood on priority list
Agency/Department: Redevelopment
Funding Sources:        Redevelopment Set-Aside Funds
Timeframe:              Identify and prioritize problem neighborhoods – 6 months; Determine
                        appropriate resources – 3 months; Determine metrics for success – 2
                        months; Concentrate resources on neighborhood until stable – as needed
Related Policies:
Measure 8.106: Receivership
To deal with blighted properties that have been vacant for an extended period of time, the City has
recourse to the option of receivership. The primary goal of this program is not to deprive property
owners of their rights, but to assist them with remedying the problems that exist with the property.
In cases where the owner cannot be contacted, or refuses to cooperate, however the City has
proactively sought the appointment of a receiver to oversee the repair and maintenance of the
property, and to ensure that the property is occupied or purchased by an owner that will maintain
the property.
Actions:    Continue to implement receivership as needed.
Agency/Department:      Redevelopment, City Administration, and Development Services
Funding Sources:        General Fund
Timeframe:              Ongoing, as needed
Related Policies:       6-1.1 to 6-1.7
Measure 8.107: Crime Free Multi-Housing
To address concerns of crimes against property and persons in multi-family housing developments
which historically have had such problems, the City will develop a Crime Free Multi-Housing
Program. This program may include such measures as a certification process for property owners
and management companies that partner with the Police Department and receive specialized
training to keep their multi-family housing crime free. The incentives to participate may include
police-issued signs for the property, certificates of participation, and advertising privileges that
would allow participating multi-family housing properties to be promoted in the media as a “crime-
free” property.
Another component could be a Crime Free Lease Addendum, which would be added to rental
agreements and would list specific criminal acts that, if committed on the property, will result in the
immediate termination of the resident’s lease.
Actions:    Develop and find funding for program; implement program in multi-family
            neighborhoods
Agency/Department: Police Department
Funding Sources:        General Fund

Measure 8.110: Preservation of At-Risk Units
The City works with individual property owners to encourage the maintenance of affordability of
assisted units. The City has 301 assisted multi-family units at risk of converting to market rates by
2010. Of the four at-risk projects, two are funded by federally derived Section 8. In addition, State,
local, or other funding sources can be used to provide rental subsidies in order to maintain the
affordability of at-risk projects. These subsidies can be structured to mirror the Section 8 program,
whereby the subsidy covers the cost of the unit above 30 percent of the tenant’s household income
(including a utility allowance) up to the fair market value of the apartment. This program can be
implemented through vouchers, so that tenants may choose where they want to live. However, the
success of such programs relies on the willingness of landlords to accept these vouchers.
Some of the options for preserving affordability should the owners decide to opt out of the Section
8 program include:
   Page       Chapter
   8-36            8

                                               IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
       Provision of financial incentives
       Transferring ownership to a non-profit housing corporation
       Provision of rent subsidies (redevelopment set-aside, CDBG, and County HOME funds)
       Purchasing similar units to be maintained as affordable housing
       Building new affordable housing units to replace the lost units
Actions:     Work with property owners to develop a strategy to maintain affordability controls on
             assisted units.
Agency/Department:       Redevelopment
Funding Sources:         Multiple Potential (Redevelopment Set-Aside, CDBG, County HOME funds)
Timeframe:               Ongoing
Related Policies:        6-2.1 to 6-2.6
Measure 8.111: Mobile Home Park Preservation
Mobile home parks provide a valuable source of affordable ownership housing in Rialto. This is
especially the case since the City has adopted a mobile home rent control ordinance. The City has
also rezoned all land occupied by mobile homes to MHD (Mobile-home Development Zone) to
protect these parks from conversion.
Actions:     Continue to oversee mobile home rent control to ensure that mobile homes remain an

Measure 8.112: Homeownership Programs
a) Homeownership Assistance Program (HAP)
The County of San Bernardino currently administers a first-time homeowners purchase program for
families of low and moderate incomes. The program assists low- and moderate-income home buyers
meet the cash requirements of a home purchase. The HAP funds may be used for gap financing,
down payment, or closing cost assistance. The assistance is in the form of a deferred loan and is
secured by a second trust deed. The program is funded by the County.
Actions:     Continue participation and advertise availability.
Agency/Department:       San Bernardino County Economic Development Services
Funding Sources:         Funded by County
Timeframe:               Ongoing
Related Policies:        6-2.1 to 6-2.6
b) Mortgage Credit Certificate
                                                                            Chapter       Page
                                                                               8          8-37

CITY OF RIALTO
General Plan
The City participates in the federal Mortgage Credit Certificate Program operated by San
Bernardino County. The MCC program allows qualified first-time homebuyers to take an annual
credit against their federal income taxes of up to 20 percent of the annual interest paid on the
applicant’s mortgage. Because of the tax credit allowance, homebuyers have more income available
to qualify for a mortgage loan and make monthly payments. Therefore, the MCC Program is a way
to further leverage homeownership assistance.
Actions: Continue participation and advertise availability
Agency/Department: San Bernardino County Economic and Development Services Funding
Sources:                Federal Tax Credit
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:
c) Fresh-Rate Program
Rialto participates in the Independent Cities Lease Finance/ Authority/ Independent Cities
Association (ICLFA/ICA) sponsored Fresh-Rate Program. This program provides a four percent down
payment and closing cost assistance. The program is financed by the ICLAFA/ICA and is limited to
Rialto residents with incomes of up to 120 percent of the County or State median income,
whichever is greater.
Actions:     Continue participation and advertise availability.
Agency/Department: ICLAFA/ICA
Funding Sources:        Private Funding
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:
d) Lease-to-Own Program
The Lease-to-Own Program, operated by the Pacific Housing & Finance Agency (PHFA), provides
down payment and closing costs for home buyers with incomes up to 140 percent of the County
median. The potential home buyer finds a home to purchase and then enters into a Lease-to-Own
Agreement with PHFA. PHDA purchase the home on behalf of the buyer and rents the home to he
buyer for a 38-month period. After 38 months, the buyer assumes the remaining year of the loan.
The program is funded by tax-exempt bonds issued by the California Cities Home Ownership
Authority.
Actions:     Continue participation and advertise availability.
Agency/Department: Pacific Housing & Finance Agency
Funding Sources:        Tax-Exempt Bonds (Issued by Joint Powers Authority)
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:
e) Officer/Teacher Next Door Program
   Page       Chapter
   8-38           8

                                                 IMPLEMENTATION PLAN

and teachers to obtain a home within the City of Rialto. The and teachers have the ability to

off the listed price. The officers or teacher are required to reside in the home a minimum of three

Measure 8.113: Section 8 Rental Assistance
The Section 8 Rental Assistance program provides rent subsidies to very low income households
who spend more than 50 percent or their income on rent. Rental assistance not only addresses
housing affordability, but also addresses overcrowding by allowing families who are “doubling up”
to afford housing. Under the certificate program, prospective renters secure housing form HUD-
registered apartments that accept the certificates. HUD pays to the landlords the difference
between what the tenant can afford to pay (30 percent of their income) and the fair market rent
(FMR). Under the voucher program, a family can choose housing that costs more than the FMR,
provided the tenant pays the additional rent. The County Housing Authority administers the Section
8 program on behalf of the City.
Actions:     Continue subsidy and encourage registration of buildings; provide information and
             referrals to landlords regarding participation in the Housing Choice Voucher Program.
Agency/Department:        County Housing Authority
Funding Sources:          Section 8 Certificates/Vouchers
Timeframe:                Ongoing
Related Policies:         6-2.1 to 6-2.6
Measure 8.114: Tenant-Based Rental Assistance
Through the Security Deposit Assistance Program, the County uses HOME funds to provide
financial assistance with required security deposits on rental housing units and tenant-paid utilities to
persons who can afford monthly rent payments but lack necessary funds to get into and/or, to avoid
being displaced from, decent housing. In addition, the County provides funds to low- and moderate-
income renter households through the Monthly Rent Subsidies Program, which is also funded by
the County HOME Program.
Actions:     Continue participation and advertise availability, including by maintaining information
             about the program and a link to the County’s Housing Development Division web page
             on the City’s website
Agency/Department: San Bernardino County Economic and Development Services
Funding Sources:          County HOME Funds

General Plan

Measure 8.116: Energy Conservation Density Bonus Program

Measure 8.119: Extremely Low Income and Special Needs Housing
Extremely low-income households and households with special needs have limited housing options.
Housing types appropriate for these groups include emergency shelters, transitional housing,
supportive housing, and single-room occupancy (SRO) units. As part of the Governmental
Constraints analysis, the following revisions to the Rialto Zoning Code, as required by State law, are
identified as appropriate to better facilitate the provision of a variety of housing types:
Actions:
        Amend the Zoning Code to facilitate housing opportunities for extremely low-income
         persons by establishing definitions, performance standards, and siting regulations for
         transitional and supportive housing development and single-room occupancy developments
         (SRO).
        Amend the Zoning Code to provide for emergency homeless shelters as a permitted use in
         at least one zone, and develop objective standards to regulate emergency shelters, as
         provided for in SB2. Develop additional written, objective standards for emergency shelters
         to regulate the following, as permitted in SB 2:
                 The maximum number of beds/persons permitted to be served nightly;
                 Off-street parking based on demonstrated need, but not to exceed parking
                  requirements for other residential or commercial uses in the same zone;
                 The size/location of exterior and interior onsite waiting and client intake areas;
                 The provision of onsite management;
                 The proximity of other emergency shelters, provided that emergency shelters are not
                  required to be more than 300 feet apart;
                 The length of stay;
                 Lighting; and
                 Security during hours that the emergency shelter is in operation.

Measure 8.120: Amend the Zoning Code to prohibit new single-family development on land
zoned for multi-family development.
Rialto’s current cumulative Zoning Code allows for single-family development to occur in all
residential zones. This can have the effect of using up scarce land available for multi-family
development with lower-density housing.
Actions:    As part of a focused Zoning Code amendment process to ensure compliance with the
            new General Plan, place minimum density limits on each zoning category.
Timeframe:              Within one year from adoption of General Plan
Agency/Department:      Development Services
Funding Sources:        General Fund
Timeframe:              Within one year from adoption of General Plan
Related Policies:       6-4.1 to 6-4.4
Measure 8.121: Fair Housing Services
The City contracts with Inland Mediation Board to provide fair housing services for its residents.
Services provided by Inland Mediation include shared housing information for senior residents,
counseling and information on housing discrimination, tenant/landlord dispute resolution, bilingual
housing literature, and testing for housing discrimination. The City will continue to provide fair
housing services through Inland Mediation and/or other agencies.
Actions:                Continue participation and advertise program availability.
Agency/Department:      Recreation and Community Services
Funding Sources:        Community Development Block Grants
Timeframe:              Ongoing
Related Policies:       6-5.1 to 6-5.3
Measure 8.122: Reasonable Accommodation Procedure
The Fair Housing Act requires that cities and counties provide reasonable accommodation to rules,
policies, practices, and procedures where such accommodation may be necessary to afford
individuals with disabilities equal opportunity to housing. The City’s Zoning Code makes special
provisions for the disabled through reduced parking requirements for senior housing and rest
homes. To create a process for making requests for reasonable accommodation to land use and
zoning decisions and procedures regulating the siting, funding, development and use of housing for
people with disabilities, the City will adopt a reasonable accommodation procedure either by
resolution or included in the Zoning Code, and will provide information to residents via public
counters and the City’s website.
